div.head: PREFACE
div.p: The Big Drum is published exactly as it was written , and as it was originally performed . At its first representation , however , the audience was reported to have been saddened by its “ unhappy ending . ” Pressure was forthwith put upon me to reconcile Philip and Ottoline at the finish , and at the third performance of the play the curtain fell upon the picture , violently and crudely brought about , of Ottoline in Philip 's arms .

I made the alteration against my principles and against my conscience , and yet not altogether unwillingly . For we live in depressing times ; and perhaps in such times it is the first duty of a writer for the stage to make concessions to his audiences and , above everything , to try to afford them a complete , if brief , distraction from the gloom which awaits them outside the theatre .

My excuse for having at the start provided an “ unhappy ” ending is that I was blind enough not to regard the ultimate break between Philip and Ottoline as really unhappy for either party . On the contrary , I looked upon the separation of these two people as a fortunate occurrence for both ; and I conceived it as a piece of ironic comedy which might not prove unentertaining that the falling away of Philip from his high resolves was checked by the woman he had once despised and who had at last grown to know and to despise herself .

titlePage.docImprint: But comedy of this order has a knack of cutting rather deeply , of ceasing , in some minds , to be comedy at all ; and it may be said that this is what has happened in the present instance . Luckily it is equally true that certain matters are less painful , because less actual , in print than upon the stage . The “ wicked publisher , ” therefore , even when bombs are dropping round him , can afford to be more independent than the theatrical manager ; and for this reason I have not hesitated to ask my friend Mr. Heinemann to publish THE BIG DRUM in its original form . ARTHUR PINEROLONDON, September1915

sp.speaker: THE BIG DRUM
sp.p: THE FIRST ACT The scene is a room , elegantly decorated , in a flat in South Audley Street . On the right , two windows give a view , through muslin curtains , of the opposite houses . In the wall facing the spectator are two doors , one on the right , the other on the left . The left-hand door opens into the room from a dimly-lighted corridor , the door on the right from the dining-room . Between the doors there is a handsome fireplace . No fire is burning and the grate is banked with flowers . When the dining-room door is opened , a sideboard and a side-table are seen in the further room , upon which are dishes of fruit , an array of ice-plates and finger-bowls , liqueurs in decanters , glasses , silver , etc . The pictures , the ornaments upon the mantelpiece , and the articles of furniture are few but choice . A high-backed settee stands on the right of the fireplace ; near the settee is a fauteuil-stool ; facing the settee is a Charles II arm-chair . On the left of the room there is a small table with a chair beside it ; on the right , not far from the nearer window , are a writing-table and writing-chair . Pieces of bric-à-brac lie upon the tables , where there are also some graceful statuettes in ivory and bronze . Another high-backed settee fills the space between the windows , and in each window there is an arm-chair of the same period as the one at the fireplace . The street is full of sunlight .

div.stage: Note : Throughout , “ right ” and “ left ” are the spectators ’ right and left , not the actor 's .
ROBERT ROOPE , seated at the writing-table , is sealing a letter . NOYES enters at the door on the left , followed by PHILIP MACKWORTH .

sp.speaker: NOYES
sp.p: Announcing PHILIP .Mr. Mackworth .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: A simple-looking gentleman of fifty , scrupulously attired — jumping up and shaking hands warmly with PHILIP as the servant withdraws .My dear Phil !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: A negligently — almost shabbily — dressed man in his late thirties , with a handsome but worn face .My dear Robbie !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: A triumph , to have dragged you out !Looking at his watch .Luncheon is n't till a quarter-to-two . I asked you for half-past-one because I want to have a quiet little jaw with you beforehand .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Delightful .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Er — I 'd better tell you at once , old chap , whom you 'll meet here to-day .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Aha ! Your tone presages a most distinguished guest .Seating himself in the chair by the small table .Is she a grande-duchesse , or is he a crowned head ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Smiling rather uneasily .Wait . I work up to my great effect by degrees . We shall only be six . Collingham Green ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: In disgust .Oh , lord !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Now , Phil , do n't be naughty .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: The fellow who does the Society gossip for the Planet !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: And does it remarkably neatly , in my opinion .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Pouah !Leaning back in his chair , his legs outstretched , and spouting .“ Mrs. Trevelyan Potter , wearing a gown of yellow charmeuse exquisitely draped with chiffon , gave a dance for her niece Miss Hermione Stubbs at the Ritz Hotel last night . ” That sort o ’ stuff !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Pained .Somebody has to supply it .

lg.l: “ Pretty Mrs. Claud Grymes came on from the opera in her pearls , and
Lady Beakly looked younger than her daughter in blue . ”

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Ruefully .You do n't grow a bit more reasonable , Phil ; not a bit .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: I beg pardon . Go ahead .

lg.l: Mrs. Godfrey Anslow and Mrs. Wally

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Bless their innocent hearts ! They 'll be glad to meet Mr. Green .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: I trust so .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Scowling .A couple of pushing , advertising women .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Really ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Ha , ha ! Sorry . That 's five , with you and me .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: That 's five , as you justly observe .Clearing his throat .H 'm ! H 'm !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: The sixth ? I prepare myself for your great effect .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: With an effort .Er — Madame de Chaumié is in London , Phil .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Sitting upright .Madame de Chaumié !Disturbed .Is she coming ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Y-y-yes .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Rising .Confound you , Robbie ——!

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Hastily .She has got rid of her house in Paris and rejoined her people . She 's with them in Ennismore Gardens .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Thank you , I 'm aware of it . One reads of Ottoline 's movements in every rag one picks up .Walking over to the right .She 's the biggest chasseuse of the crowd .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: I assure you she appears very much altered .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: What , can the leopard change his spots !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Her family may still bang the big drum occasionally , and give it an extra whack on her account ; but Ottoline herself ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Faugh !Returning to ROOPE .Why the devil have you done this ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Feebly .I confess , in the hope of bringing about a reconciliation .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: You — you good-natured old meddler .Quickly .Does she expect to find me here ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Making for the door on the left .I 'll bolt , then .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Rising and seizing him .You shall do nothing of the kind .Forcing him down upon the fauteuil-stool .You 'll upset my luncheon-table !Tidying himself .You 're most inconsiderate ; you are positively . And you 've disarranged my necktie .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: In a low voice .How is she looking , Robbie ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Brilliant .Putting his necktie in order .Is that straight ? Brilliant .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Gazing into space .Ten years ago , old man !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Quite .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: It was at her father and mother 's , in Paris , that I made your acquaintance . Recollect ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Perfectly ; in the Avenue Montaigne . I had a flat in the Palais-Royal at the time .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Scornfully .You were one of the smart set . It was worth their while to get hold of you .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: My dear Phil , do be moderately fair . You were n't in the smart set .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: No ; I was trying my hand at journalism in those days . Dreadful trade ! I was Paris correspondent to the Whitehall Gazette . That 's why I was favoured .Abruptly .Robbie ——

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Hey ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: You 'll scarcely credit it . One evening , while I was at work , Ottoline turned up with her maid at my lodgings in the Rue Soufflot , sent the maid out of the room , and proposed that I should “ mention ” her family in my letters to the Whitehall .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Mention them ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Drag in allusions to ‘ em constantly — their entertainments and so forth ; boom them , in fact .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Was that the cause of the — the final ——?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Nodding .Yes . The following week her engagement to de Chaumié was announced .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: After a slight pause .Well , in spite of all this , I 'm convinced she was genuinely attached to you , Phil — as fond of you as you were of her .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Resting his head on his hands .Oh , shut up !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Anyhow , here 's an opportunity of testing it , dear excellent friend . She 's been a widow twelve months ; you need have no delicacy on that score .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Looking up .Why , do you suggest ——?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Certainly ; and without delay . I hear there 's a shoal of men after her , including Tim Barradell .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: With a grim smile .“ Bacon ” Barradell ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Assentingly .They say Sir Timothy 's in constant attendance .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: And what chance , do you imagine , would a poor literary cove stand against a real live baronet — and the largest bacon-curer in Ireland ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Rubbing his chin .You never know . Women are romantic creatures . She might prefer the author of those absorbing works of fiction whose pages often wrap up Tim Barradell 's rashers .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Rising .Ha , ha , ha !Giving himself a shake .Even so it can n't be done , Robbie ; though I 'm grateful to you for your amiable little plot .Walking about .Heavens above , if Ottoline married me , she 'd be puffing my wares on the sly before the honeymoon was half over !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: And a jolly good job too .Moving to the left , peevishly .The truth is , my dear Phil , you 're a crank — an absolute crank — on the subject of the — ah — the natural desire of some people to keep themselves in the public eye . Mercy on us , if it comes to that , I 'm an advertiser !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: If it comes to that , you miserable old sinner , you are .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: I admit it , frankly . I own it gratifies me exceedingly to see my little dinner-parties and tea-parties , here or at my club , chronicled in the press . And it gratifies my friends also . Many of them would n't honour me at all if my list of guests was n't in the fashionable intelligence next morning .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Oh ——!

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Yes , you may roar . I declare I shudder to think of the difference it ‘ ud make to me socially if I did n't advertise .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Robbie , I blush for you .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Tosh ! It 's an advertising age .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Stalking to the fireplace .It 's a beastly vulgar age .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: It 's the age I happen to live in , and I accommodate myself to it .Pacing the room as he warms to his theme .And if it 's necessary for a private individual such as myself to advertise , as I maintain it is , how much more necessary is it for you to do so — a novelist , a poet , a would-be playwright , a man with something to sell ! Dash it , they 've got to advertise soap , and soap 's essential ! Why not literature , which is n't ? And yet you wo n't find the name of Mr. Philip Mackworth in the papers from one year 's end to another , except in a scrubby criticism now and again .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Calmly .Excuse me , there are the publisher 's announcements .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Publishers ’ announcements ! I 'm not speaking of the regular advertising columns . What I want to see are paragraphs concerning you mixed up with the news of the day , information about you and your habits , interviews with you , letters from you on every conceivable topic ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Grinning .Do you !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Joining PHILIP .Oh , my dear Phil , I entreat you , feed the papers ! It is n't as if you had n't talent ; you have . Advertising minus talent goes a long way ; advertising plus talent is irresistible . Feed the papers . The more you do for them , the more they 'll do for you . Quid pro quo . To the advertiser shall advertisement be given . Newspaper men are the nicest chaps in the world . Feed them gratis with bright and amusin ’ “ copy , ” as you term it , and they 'll love and protect you for ever .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Not for ever , Robbie . Whom the press loves die young .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: It 's fickle , you mean — some day it 'll turn and rend you ? Perhaps . Still , if you make hay while the sun shines ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: The sun ! You do n't call that the sun !Disdainfully .P'ssh !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Leaving him .Oh , I 've no patience with you !Spluttering .Upon my word , your hatred of publicity is — is — is — is morbid . It 's worse than morbid — it 's Victorian .Sitting in the chair by the small table .There ! I can n't say anything severer .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Advancing .Yes , but wait a moment , Robbie . Who says I have a hatred of publicity ? I have n't said anything so absurd . Do n't I write for the public ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Exactly !

lg.l: I have no dislike for publicity — for fame . By
George , sir , I covet it , if I can win it honestly and decently !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Shrugging his shoulders .Ah ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: And I humble myself before the men and women of my craft — and they are many — who succeed in winning it in that fashion , or who are content to remain obscure . But for the rest — the hustlers of the pen , the seekers after mere blatant applause , the pickers-up of cheap popularity — I 've a profound contempt for them and their methods .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: You can n't deny the ability of some of ‘ em .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Deny it ! Of course I do n't deny it . But no amount of ability , of genius if you will , absolves the follower of any art from the obligation of conducting himself as a modest gentleman ——

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Ah , there 's where you 're so hopelessly Victorian and out o ’ date !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Well , that 's my creed ; and , whether I 've talent or not , I 'd rather snuff out , when my time comes , neglected and a pauper than go back on it .Walking away and pacing the room .Oh , but I 'm not discouraged , my dear Robbie — not a scrap ! I 'm not discouraged , though you do regard me as a dismal failure .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Deprecatingly .No , no !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: I shall collar the great public yet . You mark me , I shall collar ‘ em yet , and without stooping to the tricks and devices you advocate !Returning to ROOPE .Robbie ——

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Rising .Hey ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Laying his hands on ROOPE 's shoulders .If my next book — my autumn book — is n't a mighty go , I — I 'll eat my hat .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Sadly .Dear excellent friend , perhaps you 'll be obliged to , for nourishment .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Ha , ha , ha !Taking ROOPE 's arm .Oddly enough — oddly enough , the story deals with the very subject we 've been discussing .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Without enthusiasm .Indeed ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Yes . You hit on the title a few minutes ago .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Really ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: When you were talking of Ottoline and her people .Dropping his voice .“ The Big Drum . ”

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Thoughtfully .C-c-capital !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Titterton , my new publisher , is tremendously taken with the scheme of the thing — keen as mustard about it .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Er — pardon me , Phil ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Eh ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Fingering the lapel of PHILIP 's coat .I say , old man , you would n't be guilty of the deplorably bad taste of putting me into it , would you ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Slapping him on the back .Ha , ha ! My dear Robbie , half the polite world is in it . Do n't tell me you wish to be left out in the cold !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Thoroughly alarmed .Dear excellent friend ——!

div.stage: NOYES enters again at the door on the left , preceding COLLINGHAM GREEN .

sp.speaker: NOYES
sp.p: Announcing GREEN , and then retiring .Mr. Collingham Green .

sp.speaker: GREEN
sp.p: A gaily-dressed , genial soul , with a flower in his button-hole , a monocle , a waxed moustache , and a skilful arrangement of a sparse head of hair — shaking hands with ROOPE .How are you , my deah fellow ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: My dear Colly , delighted to see you .

sp.speaker: GREEN
sp.p: An awful scramble to get heah . I was afraid I should n't be able to manage it .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: You 'd have broken our hearts if you had n't . You know Mackworth ?

sp.speaker: GREEN
sp.p: And his charming works .Shaking hands with PHILIP .Have n't met you for evah so long .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: How d'ye do ?

sp.speaker: GREEN
sp.p: Ouf ! I must sit down .Sitting on the fauteuil-stool and taking off a pair of delicately tinted gloves .The Season is killing me . I 'm shaw I sha'n ' t last till Goodwood , Robbie .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Yes , it 's a shockin ’ rush , is n't it !

sp.speaker: GREEN
sp.p: Haw ! You only fancy you 're rushed . Your life is a rest-cure compared with mine . You 've no conception , either of you , what my days are just now .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Finding himself addressed .Exhausting , no doubt .

sp.speaker: GREEN
sp.p: Take to-day , for example . I was in my bath at half-past-seven ——

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Half-past-seven !

sp.speaker: GREEN
sp.p: Though I was n't in bed till two this morning . At eight I had a cup of coffee and a piece of dry toast , and skimmed the papers . From eight-thirty till ten I dictated a special article on our modern English hostesses — “ The Hostesses of England : Is Hospitality Declining ? ” , a question I answer in the negative ——

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: In a murmur .Quite right .

sp.speaker: GREEN
sp.p: At ten o'clock , a man from Clapp and Beazley 's with some patterns of socks and underwear . Disposed of him , dressed , and by a quarter-to-eleven I was in the Park . Strolled up and down with Lady Ventnor and Sir Hill Birch and saw everybody there was to be seen . I nevah make a single note ; my memory 's marvellous . Left the Park at twelve and took a taxi to inquire after Lord Harrogate , Charlie Sievewright , and old Lady Dorcas Newnham . I 'm not boring you ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Boring us !

sp.speaker: GREEN
sp.p: Lady Dorcas caught sight of me from her window and hailed me in . I sat with her for twenty minutes — “ Greenie ” she always calls me —mimicking“ Now , Greenie , what 's the noos ? ” Haw , haw , haw ! I walked away from Lady Dorcas 's , and was in Upper Grosvenor Street punctually at one .To ROOPE .There 's been a meeting at the Baroness Van der Meer 's to-day , you know , over this fête at the Albert Hall .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Ah , yes ; I 'm to be in Lady Freddy Hoyle 's Plantagenet group . I 'm a knight in attendance on King John .

sp.speaker: GREEN
sp.p: I had a short private chat with the Baroness , and followed her into the drawing-room . They were still at it when I sneaked out at a side door , and heah I am .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Extraordinary ! Hey , Phil ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Leaning against the chair by the writing-table , dryly .Most interesting .

sp.speaker: GREEN
sp.p: To PHILIP , rising .I lunch with Roope —to ROOPEyou 'll have to let me off at three , Robbie — and then my grind begins again .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Throwing up his hands in admiration .Oh !

sp.speaker: GREEN
sp.p: Horse Show , two musical parties — Lady Godalming 's and Mrs. Reggie Mosenstein 's ; then home and more dictation to my secretary . Dine with Sir Patrick and Lady Logan at the Carlton , and then to the Opera with my spy-glass . From Covent Garden I dash down to Fleet Street , write my late stuff , and my day 's done — unless I 've strength left for Lady Ronaldshaw 's dance and a crush at Mrs. Hume-Cutler 's .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Repeating his former action .Oh ! Oh !

div.stage: NOYES reappears .

sp.speaker: NOYES
sp.p: Mrs. Walter Quebec .

div.stage: MRS. WALTER QUEBEC enters and NOYES withdraws .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Taking MRS. QUEBEC 's hand .My dear Mrs. Wally , how are you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. QUEBEC
sp.p: A bright , energetic , fairly young lady .How'r you , Robbie ? Walter is so grieved ; he 's lunching at the Auto with Tony Baxter . He did try to wriggle out of it —Discovering GREEN and going to him with her hand extended .Oh , I am glad ! You 're just the man I 'm dying to see .

sp.speaker: GREEN
sp.p: Kissing her hand .Haw ——!

sp.speaker: MRS. QUEBEC
sp.p: Lady Skewes and I are getting up a concert in aid of the poor sufferers from the earthquake in — what 's the name of the place ?— I forget — Lady Skewes knows it — and we want you to say a lot about us in your darling paper . Only distinguished amateurs ; that 's where the novelty comes in . Lady Skewes is going to play the violin , if she can pull herself together — she has n't played for centuries —seeing PHILIP , advancing , and shaking hands with him casuallyhow d'ye do ?—to GREENand I 've promised to sing .

sp.speaker: GREEN
sp.p: Splendid .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: But how captivating !

sp.speaker: MRS. QUEBEC
sp.p: To GREEN .I 've sung so seldom since my marriage , and they 've had such a difficulty to lure me out of my tiny wee shell . Would you mind dwelling on that a little ?

sp.speaker: GREEN
sp.p: Of course not ; anything I can do , deah lady ——

sp.speaker: MRS. QUEBEC
sp.p: That 's too utterly sweet of you . You shall have full particulars to-morrow . I would n't bother you , but it 's charity , is n't it ? Oh , and there 's something else I want you to be kind over ——!

div.stage: NOYES returns .

sp.speaker: NOYES
sp.p: Mrs. Godfrey Anslow .

div.stage: The HON . MRS. GODFREY ANSLOW enters and NOYES goes out again .

sp.speaker: MRS. ANSLOW
sp.p: A tall , languishing woman with a toneless drawl — to ROOPE .Am I late ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Pressing her hand .Not a second , my very dear friend .

lg.l: Ca n't help it if I am . My car got smashed up last week in Roehampton
Lane , and the motor people have lent me the original ark , on wheels .

sp.speaker: MRS. QUEBEC
sp.p: Shaking hands .How'r you , Millicent ?

sp.speaker: MRS. ANSLOW
sp.p: Going to GREEN and giving him her hand .Oh , and here 's that horrid Mr. Green !

sp.speaker: GREEN
sp.p: My deah Mrs. Anslow !

sp.speaker: MRS. QUEBEC
sp.p: Horrid ! What 's he done ?Sitting in the chair by the small table .I consider him a white-robed angel .

sp.speaker: MRS. ANSLOW
sp.p: I sent him a long account of my accident at Roehampton and he has n't condescended to take the slightest notice of it .

sp.speaker: MRS. QUEBEC
sp.p: Oh , Mr. Green !

sp.speaker: MRS. ANSLOW
sp.p: To GREEN .It 's cruel of you .

sp.speaker: GREEN
sp.p: To MRS. ANSLOW , twiddling his moustache .Alack and alas , deah lady , motor collisions are not quite in my line !

sp.speaker: MRS. ANSLOW
sp.p: You might have passed it on to the accident man . Or you could have said that I 'm to be seen riding in the Row evidently none the worse for my recent shock . That 's in your line .

sp.speaker: GREEN
sp.p: Haw ! I might have done that , certainly .Tapping his brow .Fact is — height of the Season — perfectly distracted ——

sp.speaker: MRS. ANSLOW
sp.p: With the air of a martyr .It does n't matter . I sha'n ' t trouble you again . I 've never been a favourite of yours ——

sp.speaker: GREEN
sp.p: Appealingly .Haw ! Do n't ——!

sp.speaker: MRS. ANSLOW
sp.p: It 's true . I was one of the few stall-holders at the Army and Navy Bazaar whose gowns you did n't describe —Seeing PHILIP and nodding to him hazily .How d'ye do ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Prompting her .Mr. Mackworth ——

div.stage: MRS. ANSLOW goes to PHILIP and proffers him a limp hand . GREEN retreats to the fireplace and MRS. QUEBEC rises and pursues him .

sp.speaker: MRS. ANSLOW
sp.p: To PHILIP .I think we met once at my cousins ’ , the Fairfields ’ .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Bowing .Yes .

sp.speaker: MRS. ANSLOW
sp.p: You write , do n't you ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Evasively .Oh ——!

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Joining them .My dear Mrs. Anslow , Mr. Mackworth is one of the most gifted authors of the present day .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Glaring at ROOPE .Tsssh !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: To MRS. ANSLOW .Get his books from your library instantly . I envy you the treat in store for you ——

div.stage: NOYES again appears .

sp.speaker: NOYES
sp.p: Madame de Chaumié .

div.stage: OTTOLINE DE CHAUMIÉ enters — a beautiful , pale , elegant young woman of three-and-thirty , with a slightly foreign air and perfect refinement of manner . NOYES retires . Everybody is manifestly pleased to see OTTOLINE , except PHILIP who picks up a little figure from the writing-table and examines it critically .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Hurrying to her and taking her hand .Ah ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Robbie dear !

sp.speaker: MRS. QUEBEC
sp.p: Going to OTTOLINE .Oh !They embrace .This is lovely !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: To MRS. ANSLOW , who comes to her .Millicent ——!To GREEN , who bustles forward and kisses her hand .How do you do ?

lg.l: You did n't stay long at the Railtons ’ last night ,

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: I had a headache — mother was so vexed with me ——

sp.speaker: MRS. ANSLOW
sp.p: Headache or not , you looked divine .

sp.speaker: MRS. QUEBEC
sp.p: A vision !

sp.speaker: GREEN
sp.p: To OTTOLINE .Haw ! I hope you saw the remarks about you in this morning 's papah , deah lady .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: To GREEN .For shame , Mr. Green ! Have you been flattering me again ?

sp.speaker: GREEN
sp.p: Haw , haw , haw , haw ——!

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Standing near PHILIP .Madame de Chaumié ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Advancing .Yes ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Here 's an old friend of ours whom you have n't met for years — Mackworth .

div.stage: She starts and then waits , rooted , for PHILIP 's approach . He replaces the figure carefully and comes to her , and their hands touch . ROOPE leaves them and engages the others in conversation .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: To PHILIP , in a low voice , her eyes sparkling .I had no idea I was to have this pleasure .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Gently , but without exceeding the bounds of mere courtesy .Robbie excels in surprises ; he has been almost equally reserved with me . Are you very well ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Very . And you ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Very . And Sir Randle and Lady Filson ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Quite well — and my brother Bertram .Chilled .Perhaps you 've heard that I am making my home with them now in London , permanently — that I 've left Paris ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Robbie — and the newspapers — have told me . It 's late in the day to do it — may I offer you my sympathy ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: With a stately inclination of the head .Thank you . And I my congratulations on your success ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Quietly .Success !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Comprehending .Ah ? Le public est si bête . I 've read every line you 've written , I believe .He bows .I — I have felt proud to think that we were once — that we were once — not des inconnus .

div.stage: He bows again , and there is silence between them . The dining-room door opens and NOYES presents himself . A waiter is seen in the dining-room , standing at the side table .

sp.speaker: NOYES
sp.p: To ROOPE .Lunch is served , sir .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: To everybody .Come along ! Come along , dear excellent friends !OTTOLINE smiles graciously at PHILIP and turns from him .Lead the way , dear Mrs. Anslow . Madame de Chaumié !MRS. ANSLOW slips her arm through OTTOLINE .You both sit opposite the fireplace . Dear Mrs. Wally ! Come along , my dear Phil !Putting an arm round GREEN 's shoulder .Colly ——!

div.stage: They all move into the dining-room , and the curtain falls . It rises again almost immediately . A chair , withdrawn from the further window , is now beside the fauteuil-stool , on its right ; and the chair which was close to the small table has been pulled out into the room , and faces the fauteuil-stool at some little distance from it . The doors are closed . MRS. ANSLOW and MRS. QUEBEC are taking their departure . The former is saying good-bye to OTTOLINE , who is standing before the fireplace ; the latter is talking to ROOPE near the door on the left . On the right is PHILIP , ready to receive his share of the adieux .

lg.l: Good-bye . You might come on to
Olympia ; my sister-in-law 's box holds six .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Sorry . I really am full up this afternoon .MRS. QUEBEC comes to OTTOLINE as MRS. ANSLOW goes to PHILIP . ROOPE opens the door on the left and remains there , waiting to escort the ladies to the outer door .Can I give you a lift anywhere , Esmé ?

sp.speaker: MRS. QUEBEC
sp.p: Thanks ; Millicent 's taking me along with her to the Horse Show .

sp.speaker: MRS. ANSLOW
sp.p: Shaking hands with PHILIP .Very pleased to meet you again . Ever see anything now of the Fairfields ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Never .

sp.speaker: MRS. ANSLOW
sp.p: No loss . I believe dear old Eustace is off his head .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Possibly .

sp.speaker: MRS. ANSLOW
sp.p: Tolerantly .But then , so many people are off their heads , are n't they ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: A great many .

sp.speaker: MRS. ANSLOW
sp.p: Bestowing a parting nod upon PHILIP and crossing to the open door .Sha'n ' t wait , Esmé . It 's a month 's journey to Hammersmith in the ark .

sp.speaker: MRS. QUEBEC
sp.p: Kissing OTTOLINE .Good-bye .

sp.speaker: MRS. ANSLOW
sp.p: To ROOPE .Charming lunch . Enjoyed myself enormously .

sp.speaker: MRS. QUEBEC
sp.p: Shaking hands with PHILIP hastily .Good-bye , Mr. Mackworth .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Good-bye .

div.stage: ROOPE and MRS. ANSLOW have disappeared ; MRS. QUEBEC follows them . OTTOLINE approaches PHILIP slowly .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Giving him her hand .Good-bye .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Bending over it formally .Good-bye .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: We — we 're in Ennismore Gardens , you know .He acknowledges the information by a stiff bow . She interests herself in her glove-buttons .You — you 've chosen to drop out of my — out of our lives so completely that I hardly like to ask you to come and see us .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Constrainedly .You are very good ; but I — I do n't go about much in these days , and I 'm afraid ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Quickly .Oh , I 'm sure you 're wise .Drawing herself erect .A writer should n't give up to society what is meant for mankind , should he ?

div.stage: She passes him distantly , to leave the room , and he suddenly grips her shoulder .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Ottoline ——!

div.stage: By a mutual impulse , they glance swiftly at the open door , and then she throws herself into his arms .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Philip ——!

div.stage: Just as swiftly , they separate ; and a moment afterwards ROOPE returns , rubbing his hands cheerily .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Advancing , but not shutting the door .There ! Now we 're by ourselves !To OTTOLINE .You 're not running away ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Confused .Oh , I — I ——

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: It 's only half-past-three . Why do n't you and Mackworth sit down and have a little talk together ?To PHILIP , who has strolled to the further window and is looking into the street .You 're in no hurry , Phil ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Not in the least .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Crossing to the writing-table .I 'll finish answering my letters ; I sha'n ' t have a moment later on .Gathering up his correspondence .You wo n't disturb me ; I 'll polish ‘ em off in another room .To OTTOLINE .Are you goin ’ to Lady Paulton 's by-and-by , by any chance ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Again at the fireplace , her back to ROOPE and PHILIP .And Mrs. Jack Cathcart 's — and Mrs . Le Roy 's ——

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: You shall take me to Lowndes Square , if you will .Recrossing .Sha'n ' t be more than ten minutes .At the door .Ten minutes , dear excellent friends . A quarter-of-an-hour at the outside .

div.stage: He vanishes , closing the door . There is a pause , and then PHILIP and OTTOLINE turn to one another and he goes to her .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Her hands in his , breathlessly .You are glad to see me , then !Laughing shyly .Ha , ha ! You are glad !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Tenderly .Yes .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: You brute , Phil , to make me behave in such an undignified way !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: If there 's any question of dignity , what on earth has become of mine ? I was the first to break down .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: To break down ! Why should you try to treat me so freezingly ? You can n't be angry with me still , after all these years ! C'est pas possible !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: It was stupid of me to attempt to hide my feelings .Pressing her hand to his lips .But , my dear Otto — my dear girl — where 's the use of our coming into each other 's lives again ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: The use —? Why should n't we be again as we were in the old Paris days —embarrassedwell , not quite , perhaps ——?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Smiling .Oh , of course , if you command it , I am ready to buy some smart clothes , and fish for opportunities of meeting you occasionally on a crowded staircase or in a hot supper-room . But — as for anything else ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Slowly withdrawing her hands and putting them behind her .As for — anything else ——?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: I repeat — cui bono ?Regarding her kindly but penetratingly .What would be the result of your reviving a friendship with an ill-tempered , intolerant person who would be just as capable to-morrow of turning upon you like a savage ——?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Ah , you are still angry with me !With a change of tone .As you did that evening , for instance , when I came with Nannette to your shabby little den in the Rue Soufflot ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Precisely .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Walking away to the front of the fauteuil-stool .To beg you to prôner my father and mother in the journal you were writing for — what was the name of it ?——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Following her .The Whitehall Gazette .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: And you were polite enough to tell me that my cravings and ideals were low , pitiful , ignoble !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Regretfully .You remember ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Facing him .As clearly as you do , my friend .Laying her hand upon his arm , melting .Besides , they were true — those words — hideously true — as were many other sharp ones you shot at me in Paris .Turning from him .Low — pitiful — ignoble ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Otto ——!

div.stage: She seats herself in the chair by the fauteuil-stool and motions him to sit by her . He does so .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Yes , they were true ; but they are true of me no longer . I am greatly changed , Philip .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Eyeing her .You are more beautiful than ever .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: H'sh !— changed in my character , disposition , view of things . Life has gone sadly with me since we parted .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Indeed ? I — I 'm grieved .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: My marriage was an utter failure . You heard ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Shaking his head .No .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: No ?Smiling faintly .I thought everybody hears when a marriage is a failure .Mournfully .The fact remains ; it was a terrible mistake . Poor Lucien ! I do n't blame him for my nine years of unhappiness . I engaged myself to him in a hurry — out of pique ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Pique ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Within a few hours of that fatal visit of mine to your lodgings .Looking at him significantly .It was that that drove me to it .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Staring at her .That ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Simply .Yes , Phil .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Otto !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Plucking at the arm of her chair .You see — you see , notwithstanding the vulgarity of my mind , I had a deep respect for you . Even then there were wholesome signs in me !Shrugging her shoulders plaintively .Whether I should have ended by obeying my better instincts , and accepting you , I can n't say . I believe I should . I — I believe I should . At any rate , I had already begun to chafe under the consciousness that , while you loved me , you had no esteem for me .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Remorsefully .My dear !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Raising her head .That scene between us in the Rue Soufflot set my blood on fire . To have a request refused me was sufficiently mortifying ; but to be whipped , scourged , scarified , into the bargain —! I flew down your stairs after I left you , and drove home , scorching with indignation ; and next morning I sent for Lucien — a blind adorer !— and promised to be his wife .Leaning back .Comprenez-vous , maintenant ? Solely to hurt you ; to hurt you , the one man among my acquaintances whom I — admired !

div.stage: She searches for her handkerchief . He rises and goes to the mantelpiece and stares at the flowers in the grate .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Almost inaudibly .Oh , Otto !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Wiping a tear from her cheek .Heigh , dear me ! Whenever I go over the past , and that 's not seldom , I can n't help thinking you might have been a little gentler with me — a girl of three-and-twenty — and have made allowances .Blowing her nose .What was Dad before he went out to Buenos Aires with his wife and children ; only a junior partner in a small concern in the City ! Was n't it natural that , when he came back to Europe , prosperous but a nobody , he should be eager to elbow himself into a respectable social position , and that his belongings should have caught the fever ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Wretchedly .Yes — yes ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Rising and wandering to the writing-table .First we descended upon Paris — you know ; but Paris did n't respond very satisfactorily . Plenty of smart men flocked round us — la belle Mademoiselle Filson drew them to the Avenue Montaigne !——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Under his breath , turning .T'scht !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: But the women were either hopelessly bourgeoises or slightly déclassée .Inspecting some of the pieces of bric-à-brac upon the table .Which decided us to attack London — and induced me to pay my call on you in the Rue Soufflot ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: I understand .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: To coax you to herald us in your weekly causeries .Wincing .Horrible of me , that was ; horrible , horrible , horrible !Replacing an object upon the table and moving to the other side of the room .However , I was n't destined to share the earliest of the London triumphs .Bitterly .Mine awaited me in Paris , and at Vaudemont-Baudricourt , as the Comtesse de Chaumié !Shivering .Ugh-h-h-h ——!

div.stage: She is about to sit in the chair on the left when he comes to her impulsively and restrains her .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: My poor girl ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: With abandon .Ah ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: My poor dear girl !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: It 's a relief to me to open my heart to you , Philip .He leads her to the fauteuil-stool .Robbie wo n't interrupt us yet awhile , will he ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: We 'll kick him out if he does .They sit , close together , upon the fauteuil-stool .Oh , but he wo n't ! This is a deep-laid plot of the old chap 's ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Plot ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: To invite us here to-day , you and me , to — to ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Amener un rapprochement ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Exactly .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Softly .Ha , ha ! Dear old Robbie !He laughs with her .Dear , dear old Robbie !Her laughter dies out , leaving her with a serious , appealing face .Phil ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Eh ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Your sneer — your sneer about me and the papers ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Sneer ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: I detected it . Almost the first thing you said to me when I arrived was that you 'd been gathering news of me lately from the papers !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Gently .Forgive me .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: It 's been none of my doing ; I 've finished with le snobbisme entirely .Pleadingly .You do n't doubt me ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Patting her hand .No — no .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Nowadays I detest coming across my name in print . But my people —with a little mouethey will persist in ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Beating the big drum ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Ha !Brushing her hair from her brow fretfully .Oh ! Oh , Phil , it was blindness on my part to return to them — sheer blindness !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Blindness ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: They 've been urging me to do it ever since my husband 's death ; so I had ample time to consider the step . But I did n't realize , till I 'd settled down in Ennismore Gardens , how thoroughly I ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Finding she does n't continue .How thoroughly ——?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: How thoroughly I 've grown away from them — ceased to be one of them .Stamping her foot .Oh , I know I 'm ungrateful ; and that they 're proud of me , and pet and spoil me ;contracting her shoulder-bladesbut they make my flesh feel quite raw — mother , Dad , and my brother Bertram ! Their intense satisfaction with themselves , and everything appertaining to them , irritates me to such a pitch that I 'm often obliged to rush out of the room to stop myself from being rude .Impetuously .And then to have to watch Dad and mother still pushing , scheming , intriguing ; always with the affectation of despising réclame , yet doing nothing — not the most simple act — without a careful eye to it ! Years ago , as I 've said , there was an intelligible motive for our paltry ambitions ; but now , when they have forcé les portes and can afford to be sincere and independent ——!Checking herself .But I ought n't to speak of my folks like this , ought I , even to you whom I can trust !Penitently .It 's awfully wrong of me . I — I beg your pardon .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: After a short silence .What do you intend to do , then , Otto , ultimately — re-establish yourself in Paris ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Drearily .Paris ! Is Paris so full of cheerful memories for me , do you suppose , that I should cling to it !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Soothingly .Oh , come ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: I travelled about for some months after I became a widow , and when I saw Paris again —!Starting up as if to rid herself of disagreeable sensations .No , my one great desire is to escape from it all , Phil —moving to the chair on the leftto escape ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Rising .Escape ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: To alter the whole current of my life , if it 's possible ,sinking into the chairand to breathe some fresh air !Fanning herself with her hand .Phew-w-w-w !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: H 'm !Approaching her and looking down upon her .According to report , Ottoline , you 'd have very little difficulty in — escaping .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Glancing up at him .Report ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Rumour has it that there are at least a dozen ardent admirers at your feet , each with a wedding-ring in his waistcoat-pocket .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Reproachfully , her eyes meeting his .Why , have you been listening to tittle-tattle as well as studying newspaper paragraphs !He bows , good-humouredly .My dear Philip , allowing for exaggeration , granting that my soupirants number half-a-dozen , which of them would enable me to fill my lungs with fresh air ? Who are they , these enterprising men ——?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Leaving her abruptly and going to the mantelpiece .Oh , pray do n't ask me ! I do n't know who the fellows are — except — they say — Sir Timothy Barradell ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Lightly but softly .Sir Timothy ! Sir Timothy has only just succeeded in fighting his way into the world I 'm sick and tired of !Shaking her head .Poor Sir Tim !Pityingly .Ha , ha , ha , ha !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: His back towards her .Otto ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: What sort of world would you be willing to exchange for your present one , my dear ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: What sort ——?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: What sort — spiritual and material ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Resting her elbow upon the arm of her chair and her chin upon her hand , musingly .Oh , I believe any world would content me that 's totally different from the world I 've lived in so long ; any world that is n't flat and stale and stifling ; that is n't made up of shams , and petty aims and appetites ; any world that — well , such a world as you used to picture , Phil , when you preached your gospel to a selfish , common girl under the chestnuts in the Allée de Longchamp and the Champs-Elysées !Half laughing , half sighing .Ha , la , la , la !

div.stage: Again there is a pause , and then he walks to the further window and gazes into the street once more .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: In a low voice .Ten years ago , Otto !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Ten years ago !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Partly in jest , partly seriously .Do the buds still sprout on those trees in the Allée de Longchamp and the Champs-Elysées , can you tell me ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Falling in with his humour .Ha , ha ! Every spring , cher ami , regularly .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: And the milk at the Café d'Armenonville and the Pré-Catelan — is it still rich and delectable ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: To the young , I assume ; scarcely to the aged widow ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Or the grey-haired scribbler ! Ha , ha , ha , ha !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Ha , ha , ha , ha ——!

div.stage: He turns and advances to her slowly , looking at her fixedly and earnestly .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Ottoline — I wonder whether you 'd care to walk under those trees with me again , for sentiment 's sake , some fine day in the future ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Staring at him .C-care ——?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: And if you would , whether I ought to tempt you to risk it !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Rising , smiling but discomposed .To — to risk finding that le lait n'est pas crémeux , do you mean ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Tenderly .To risk even that .Drawing nearer to her .Otto ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: I — I should be delighted — if — if ever ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: No , no ; not as friends , Otto — save in the best sense ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Faintly .I — I do n't ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: As husband and wife .She stands quite still .Husband and wife ! Some day when I 've achieved a solid success ; when I 've captured the great public , and can come to you , not as a poor , struggling writer , but holding my prizes in both hands !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Putting her hand to her forehead .It — it 's not too late , is it ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Recoiling .Too late — for me — to be successful ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Passionately .Oh , my God , do n't say that to me —going to him , and clinging to himtoo late for me to recover a little of what I 've lost !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Pressing her to him .Ah ! Too late for neither of us . It 's a bargain ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Yes — yes ; but ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: But ——?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Her head drooping .Must it be — some day ?Piteously .Some day !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: There are signs in the sky ; the day is n't far distant !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: I — I 've money , Philip ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: H'sssh !Frowning .Ottoline !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Ah , je vois que votre orgueil est plus fort que votre amour !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Ha , ha ! Peut-être ; je ne m'en défends pas . You consent ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Pouting .I may let my people know of the arrangement , may I not ? You 'll see them ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: My dear , what would be gained by that now ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: It would enable you to come often to Ennismore Gardens , and have cosy teas with me in my room . We could n't be — what we are — on the sly indefinitely ; it 's impracticable . There 'll be a storm at first , but it will soon blow over .Making a wry face .Still , if you 'd rather ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: No , no ; I 'll see them , if you wish me to .Nodding .We 'll be open and above-board from the start .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Ha , ha !Sighing happily .Ah-h-h-h !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: His tone changing to one of misgiving .Ah , Otto , I begin to be afraid that I ought n't — that I ought n't to have spoken to you ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Gravely .You will never be patient — you 'll never be content to wait , if need be !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Content , no . But patient !In a whisper .Shall I tell you a secret ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: I 've been waiting — waiting for you — in my dreams — for ten years !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Ardently .Otto ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Is n't that patience ?

div.stage: Their lips meet in a lingering kiss . The handle of the door on the left is heard to rattle . Looking at the door , they draw back from one another . The handle rattles again .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: It 's that idiot Robbie .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Ha , ha , ha , ha ——!

div.stage: The door opens , and ROOPE appears , with an air of unconcern .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Humming .Tra , lal , lal , la ——! That 's done , dear excellent friends !Closing the door , and coming forward .Upon my word , letters are the curse of one 's existence ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Ha , ha ——!Seizing him .Robbie ——!

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Startled .Hey ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: I can n't take you to Lady Paulton 's — or anywhere else . Philip and I are going to spend the rest of the afternoon here , if you 'll let us — and talk — and talk ——!Suddenly embracing him , and kissing him upon the cheek .Ah ! Que vous êtes gentil ! Merci — merci — merci ——!Sitting in the chair on the left and unpinning her hat .Ha , ha , ha , ha ——!

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Turning to PHILIP , his eyes bolting .Phil ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Nodding .Yes .Wringing ROOPE 's hand .Much obliged , Robbie . END OF THE FIRST ACT

div.head: THE SECOND ACT

stage.stage: The scene is a morning-room , richly furnished and decorated , in a house in Ennismore Gardens . The walls are of panelled wood for two-thirds of their height , the rest being covered with silk . In the wall at the back , between the centre and the left-hand corner , there is a handsome double-door opening upon another door , covered in thick cloth , which is supposed to give admittance to the library . On the right , in a piece of wall running obliquely towards the spectator from the back wall to the right-hand wall , is a companion double-door to that on the left , with the difference that the panels of the upper part of this door are glazed . A silk curtain obscures the glazed panels to the height of about seven feet from the floor , and above the curtain there is a view of a spacious hall . When the glazed door is opened , it is seen that the hall is appropriately furnished . A window is at the further end of it , letting in light from the street , and on the right of the window there is a lofty screen arranged in such a manner as to suggest that it conceals the front door of the house .

The fireplace , where a bank of flowers hides the grate , is in the left-hand wall of the room . On the further side of the fireplace there is an armchair , and before the fireplace a settee . Behind the settee , also facing the fireplace , are a writing-table and chair ; close to the further side of the writing-table is a smaller chair ; and at the nearer end of the settee , but at some distance from it , stands a low-backed arm-chair which is turned in the direction of the door on the right .

On the other side of the room , facing the spectator and following the line of the oblique wall , is a second settee . On the left of this settee is an arm-chair , on the right a round table and another chair . Books and periodicals are strewn upon the table . Against the wall at the back , between the doors , are an oblong table and a chair ; and other articles of furniture and embellishment — cabinets of various kinds , jardinières , mirrors , lamps , etc ., etc .— occupy spaces not provided for in this description .
Among other objects upon the oblong table are some framed photographs , conspicuously displayed , of members of the Royal Family , and a book-rack containing books of reference .

[ MISS TRACER , a red-haired , sprightly young lady , is seated upon the settee on the right , turning the leaves of a picture-paper . A note-book , with a pencil stuck in it , lies by her side . There is a knock at the door on the left .

sp.speaker: MISS TRACER
sp.p: Calling out .Eh ?

div.stage: The door opens and LEONARD WESTRIP appears . He carries a pile of press-cuttings .

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: A fresh-coloured , boyish young man .I beg your pardon ——seeing that MISS TRACER is aloneoh , good morning .

sp.speaker: MISS TRACER
sp.p: Good morning .

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: Entering and closing the door .Lady Filson is n't down yet ?

sp.speaker: MISS TRACER
sp.p: No .Tossing the picture-paper onto the round table .She did n't get to bed till pretty late last night , I suspect .

lg.l: I thought she 'd like to look through these .

sp.speaker: MISS TRACER
sp.p: Picking up her note-book and rising .You bet she would !

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: Handing her the press-cuttings .Let me have them back again , please . Sir Randle hardly had time to glance at them before he went out .

sp.speaker: MISS TRACER
sp.p: Inquisitively , elevating her eyebrows .He 's out very early ?

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: Yes ; he 's gone to a memorial service .

sp.speaker: MISS TRACER
sp.p: Another !With a twinkle .That 's the third this month .

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: So it is . I 'm awfully sorry for him .

sp.speaker: MISS TRACER
sp.p: Laughing slyly .He , he , he ! Ho , ho !

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: Surprised .What is there to laugh at , Miss Tracer ?

sp.speaker: MISS TRACER
sp.p: You do n't believe he has ever really known half the people he mourns , do you ?

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: Not known them !

sp.speaker: MISS TRACER
sp.p: Crossing to the writing-table and laying the press-cuttings upon it .Guileless youth ! Wait till you 've breathed the air of this establishment a little longer .

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: Puzzled .But if he has n't known them , why should he ——?

sp.speaker: MISS TRACER
sp.p: For the sake of figuring among a lot of prominent personages , of course .

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: Incredulously .Oh , Miss Tracer !

sp.speaker: MISS TRACER
sp.p: Gospel .Taking up the press-cuttings and looking through them .Many are the sympathetic souls who are grief-stricken in these days for the same reason . Here we are !Reading from a cutting .Late Viscount Petersfield ... memorial service ... St. Margaret 's , Westminster ... among those present ... h 'm , h 'm , h 'm ... Sir Randle Filson ... wreaths were sent by ... h 'm , h 'm , h 'm , h 'm ... Sir Randle and Lady Filson !Replacing the press-cuttings upon the table .Ha , ha , ha , ha —!Checking herself and turning to WESTRIP .Our conversation is strictly private , Mr. Westrip ?

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: Somewhat disturbed .Strictly .

sp.speaker: MISS TRACER
sp.p: Smiling at him winningly and moving to the settee before the fireplace .You 're a nice boy ; I 'm sure you would n't make mischief .Sinking on to the settee with a yawn .Oh ! Oh , I 'm so weary !

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: Weary ? Before you 've begun your morning 's work !

sp.speaker: MISS TRACER
sp.p: Before I 've begun it ! I had a parade downstairs in the servants ’ hall at a quarter-to-ten .

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: Parade ?

sp.speaker: MISS TRACER
sp.p: We 've two new women in the house who are perfect idiots . They can n't remember to say “ yes , my lady ” and “ no , my lady ” and “ very good , my lady ” whenever Lady Filson speaks to them . One of them actually addressed her yesterday as “ ma'am . ” I wonder the roof did n't fall in .

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: Meditatively .I 've noticed that Sir Randle and Lady Filson have a great relish for being Sir 'd and Lady 'd .

sp.speaker: MISS TRACER
sp.p: Ha , ha ! Rather !Over her shoulder .You take a friendly hint . If your predecessor had Sir Randle 'd and Lady Filson 'd them more frequently , you would n't be standing in his shoes at this moment .

lg.stage: In the middle of the room , his hands in his pockets .

lg.l: Built a large drill-hall for the Territorials near his country place at

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: Innocently .Oh , is he interested in the Territorials ?

sp.speaker: MISS TRACER
sp.p: Partly raising herself .Interested in the Territorials ! How simple you are ! He cares as much for the Territorials as I care for snakes .Kneeling upon the settee and resting her arms on the back of it , talkatively .The drill-hall was her notion ; she engineered the whole affair .

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: Opening his eyes wider and wider .Lady Filson ?

sp.speaker: MISS TRACER
sp.p: Nodding .Her maid 's my informant . A few years ago he was growing frightfully down-in-the-mouth . He fancied he 'd got stuck , as it were — that everybody was getting an honour but himself . So the blessed shanty was run up in a devil of a hurry — excuse my Greek ; and as soon as it was dry , Mrs. Filson , as she then was , wrote to some big-wig or other — without her husband 's knowledge , she explained — and called attention to the service he 'd rendered to the cause of patriotism . Lambert saw the draft of the letter on her mistress 's dressing-table .Shaking with laughter .Ho , ho , ho ! And what d'ye think ?

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: W-well ?

sp.speaker: MISS TRACER
sp.p: The corrections were in his handwriting !

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: Shocked .In Sir Randle 's ——!

sp.speaker: MISS TRACER
sp.p: Jumping up .Phiou ! I 'm fearfully indiscreet .Going to WESTRIP and touching his coat-sleeve .Between ourselves , Mr. Westrip !

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: Moving to the round table .Quite — quite .

sp.speaker: MISS TRACER
sp.p: Following him .Oh , they 're not a bad sort , by any means , if you just humour them a bit . We all have our little weaknesses , have n't we ? I 've mine , I confess .

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: They 've both been excessively kind to me .Turning to her .And as for Madame de Chaumié ——

sp.speaker: MISS TRACER
sp.p: Oh , she 's a dear — a regular dear !

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: Fervently .By Jove , is n't she !

sp.speaker: MISS TRACER
sp.p: But then , my theory is that she was changed at her birth . She 's not a genuine Filson , I 'll swear .Suddenly walking away from him .H'sh !

div.stage: LADY FILSON , a handsome , complacent woman of about fifty-seven , enters from the hall .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Who carries a hand-bag crammed with letters , cards of invitation , etc .Good morning . MISS TRACER and WESTRIP . Good morning , Lady Filson .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Closing the door and advancing .Oh , Mr. Westrip , I wish you 'd try to find the last number of the Trifler . It must have been taken out of my bedroom by one of the servants .

lg.stage: Searching among the periodicals on the round table .

sp.speaker: MISS TRACER
sp.p: Oh , Lady Filson , do n't keep that horrid snapshot of you and Sir Randle ! It 's too unflattering .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: At the writing-table .As if that mattered ! So are the portraits of Lord and Lady Sturminster on the same page .Sitting at the table and emptying her bag .These absurd things give Sir Randle and me a hearty laugh ; that 's why I preserve them .

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: It is n't here .Going to the glazed door .I 'll hunt for it downstairs .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Thank you .Discovering the pile of press-cuttings .What 's this ?Affecting annoyance .Not more press-cuttings !Beginning to devour the cuttings .Tcht , tcht , tcht !

div.stage: As WESTRIP reaches the door , BERTRAM FILSON enters . He is wearing riding-dress .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: A conceited , pompous young man of thirty .Good morning , Mr. Westrip .

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: Good morning , Mr. Filson .

div.stage: WESTRIP goes out , closing the door .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: To MISS TRACER .Good morning , Miss Tracer .

sp.speaker: MISS TRACER
sp.p: Who has seated herself in the chair at the further side of the writing-table — meekly .Good morning .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Half turning to BERTRAM , the press-cuttings in her hand .Ah , my darling ! Was that you I saw speaking to Underwood as I came through the hall ?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Yes , mother dear .Bending over her and kissing her .How are you ?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Dotingly .Enjoyed your ride , my pet ?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Fairly , mother .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Only fairly ?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Shutting his eyes .Such an appalling crowd of ordinary people in the Row , I mean t'say .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: How dreadful for you !Giving him the press-cuttings .Sit down , if you 're not too warm , and look at this rubbish while I talk to Miss Tracer .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Press-cuttings ?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Is n't it strange , the way the papers follow all our doings !

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Not in the least , mother .Sitting upon the settee on the right and reading the press-cuttings .I mean t'say , I consider it perfectly right and proper .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Sorting her letters and cards — to MISS TRACER .There 's not much this morning , Miss Tracer .Handing some letters to MISS TRACER .You can deal with these .

sp.speaker: MISS TRACER
sp.p: Thank you , Lady Filson .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Reading a letter .Lady Skewes and Mrs. Walter Quebec ... arranging a concert in aid of ...sighingtickets , of course !... what tiring women !...turning the sheetoh !... may they include me in their list of patronesses ?... Princess Cagliari-Tamponi , the Countess of Harrogate , the Viscountess Chepmell , Lady Kathleen Tring ...laying the letter asidedelighted .Heaping together the cards and the rest of the letters .I must answer those myself .To MISS TRACER .That 's all .MISS TRACER rises .Get on with the invitations for July the eighth as quickly as you can .

sp.speaker: MISS TRACER
sp.p: Going to the glazed door .Yes , Lady Filson .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Turning .Miss Tracer ——

sp.speaker: MISS TRACER
sp.p: Halting .Yes , Lady Filson ?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: I think Madame de Chaumié wants you to do some little commissions for her . Kindly see her before you go to your room .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: To MISS TRACER , looking up .No , no ; do n't .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: To BERTRAM .Not ?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: My sister is engaged , mother .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Engaged ?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: With Sir Timothy Barradell .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Oh —?To MISS TRACER .By-and-by , then .

sp.speaker: MISS TRACER
sp.p: Yes , Lady Filson .

div.stage: MISS TRACER departs , closing the door .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: To BERTRAM , eagerly .Sir Timothy ——!

lg.l: He called half-an-hour ago , mother , Underwood tells me , with a note for

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: From himself ?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Presumably ; and Dilworth came down and took him up to her boudoir .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Rising .An unusual time of day for a call !Approaching BERTRAM and speaking under her breath .Are matters coming to a head between them , my dear boy ?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Do n't ask me , mother .Rising .You are as capable of forming an opinion as I am , I mean t'say .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: I 've a feeling that something is in the air . He positively shadowed her last night at the Gorhams ’ !

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Knitting his brows .I admit I should prefer , if my sister contemplates marrying again , that her choice fell on one of the others .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Mr. Trefusis — or George Delacour ——?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Even Trevor Wilson .Wincing .The idea of a merchant brother-in-law does n't appeal to me very strongly , I mean t'say .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Still , a baronet ——!

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: And I suppose ——?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Oh , enormously !

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Magnanimously .Anyhow , my dear mother , if Ottoline is fond of the man , I promise you that not a murmur from me shall mar their happiness .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Tenderly , pinching his chin .My darling !

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: With a shiver .I 'm afraid I am getting a little chilled ;giving her the press-cuttingsI 'll go and change .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Oh , my pet , run away at once !

div.stage: She moves to the settee on the right . He pauses to gaze at her .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: You look exceedingly handsome this morning , mother .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Gratified .Do I , Bertram ?Seating herself upon the settee , and again applying herself to the press-cuttings , as BERTRAM goes to the glazed door .In spite of my late hours !

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Opening the door .Here 's my father ——

div.stage: SIR RANDLE FILSON enters , dressed in mourning . He is a man of sixty-three , of commanding presence , with a head resembling that of Alexandre Dumas Fils in the portrait by Meissonier , and a bland , florid manner . He seems to derive much satisfaction from listening to the rich modulations of his voice .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Bertram , my boy !Kissing him upon the cheek .Been riding , eh ?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Yes . I 'm just going to change , father .

lg.l: That 's right ; do n't risk catching cold , whatever you do .
lg.stage: Seeing LADY FILSON and coming forward .
lg.l: Ah , your dear mother is down !

div.stage: BERTRAM goes out , closing the door .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Beaming upon SIR RANDLE .You have n't been long , Randle .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: A cloud overshadowing his face .I did n't remain for the Dead March , Winnie .Taking off his black gloves .I need hardly have troubled to go at all , as it turned out .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Why , dear ?

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: The sad business was most abominably mismanaged . No reporters .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: No reporters !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Not a single pressman in the porch .Blowing into a glove .Pfhh ! Poor old Macfarlane !Pulling at his second glove .The public will never learn the names of those who assembled , at serious inconvenience to themselves , to pay respect to his memory .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Shocking !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Blowing .Pfhh !Folding the gloves neatly .I am almost glad , in the circumstances , that I did n't regard it as an event which laid me under an obligation to send flowers .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: With a change of tone .Er — Randle ——

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Putting his gloves into his tail-pocket .Yes , dear .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Significantly .Sir Timothy is upstairs .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Sir Timothy Barradell ?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Nodding .With Ottoline , in her sitting-room .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Indeed ?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: He brought a note for her half-an-hour ago , evidently asking her to receive him .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Going to LADY FILSON .An early call !

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Extremely .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Sitting near her , in the arm-chair on the left of the settee , and pursing his lips .It may mean nothing .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Oh , nothing .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Examining his nails .A nice , amiable fellow .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Full of fine qualities , if I 'm any judge of character .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: None the worse for being self-made , Winnie .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Not in my estimation .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: H 'm , h 'm , h 'm , h 'm ——!

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Softly .It would n't sound bad , Randle .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Leaning back in his chair and closing his eyes .“ Lady Barradell . ”

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: In the same way .“ Lady Barradell . ”

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: In a murmur , but with great gusto .“ A marriage is arranged and will shortly take place between Sir Timothy Barradell , Bart ., of 16 , The Albany , and Bryanstown Park , County Wicklow , and Ottoline , widow of the late Comte de Chaumié , only daughter of Sir Randle and Lady Filson , of 71 , Ennismore Gardens , and Pickhurst , Bramsfold , Sussex . ”

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: After a short pause , in a low voice .Darling Ottoline ! What a wedding she shall have !

div.stage: Again there is a pause , and then SIR RANDLE leaves his chair and seats himself beside LADY FILSON .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Putting his arm round her , fondly .Mother !

div.stage: They look at one another , and he draws her to him and kisses her . As he does so , the glazed door opens and WESTRIP returns , carrying an illustrated-weekly . LADY FILSON rises hastily and goes to the writing-table .

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: Handing her the paper .It was in the servants ’ hall , Lady Filson .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Laying the paper and the press-cuttings upon the writing-table , and sitting at the table and busying herself with her letters .Thank you so much .

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: To SIR RANDLE .Are you ready for me now , Sir Randle ?

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Abstractedly .Er — is there anything of grave importance to-day , Mr. Westrip ? I forget .

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: Coming to him .Boxfield and Henderson , the photographers , are anxious to photograph you and Lady Filson for their series of “ Notable People , ” Sir Randle .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Rolling his head from side to side .Oh ! Oh , dear ; oh , dear !

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Wearily .Oh , dear !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: How we are pestered , Lady Filson and I !

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Terrible !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: No peace ! No peace !

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Or privacy .

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: Producing a note-book from his pocket .They will attend here any morning convenient to you and Lady Filson , Sir Randle . It wo n't take ten minutes .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: To LADY FILSON , resignedly .Winnie ——?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Entering the appointment on a tablet .Tuesday at eleven .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: To WESTRIP .Remind me .

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: Writing in his note-book .Yes , Sir Randle .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: And advise Madame de Chaumié and Mr. Bertram , with my love , of the appointment . Her ladyship and I will be photographed with our children grouped round us .

lg.l: Then there 's the telegram from the Daily Monitor ,

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Puffing himself out .Ah , yes ! The editor solicits my views upon — what is the subject of the discussion which is being carried on in his admirable journal , Mr . Westrip ?——

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: “ Should Women Marry under Thirty ? ”

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: Forty-eight words .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Rising and strolling across to LADY FILSON , as if seeking for inspiration .Should Women Marry under Thirty ?Humming .H 'm , h 'm , h 'm —!To LADY FILSON .Winnie ——?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Looking up at him .I was considerably under thirty when we married , Randle .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Triumphantly .Ha !Chuckling .Ho , ho , ho ! Capital ! Ho , ho , ho !Patting LADY FILSON 's shoulder .Clever ! Clever !To WESTRIP , grandly .There we have my response to the inquiry , Mr. Westrip .Closing his eyes again .Sir Randle Filson 's views are best expressed by the statement that Lady Filson was considerably under thirty when she did him the honour of — er — becoming his wife .

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: Excellent , sir .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Opening his eyes .Pray amplify that in graceful language , Mr. Westrip — restricting yourself to forty-eight words —He breaks off , interrupted by the appearance of OTTOLINE at the glazed door .Ah , my darling !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Good morning , Dad .To WESTRIP .Good morning .

sp.speaker: WESTRIP
sp.p: Shyly .Good morning .

lg.stage: To SIR RANDLE — advancing a few steps , but leaving the door open .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Not at all .

lg.stage: Who has turned in her chair at OTTOLINE 's entrance .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: To WESTRIP .I will join you in the library , Mr. Westrip .WESTRIP withdraws at the door on the left , and SIR RANDLE goes to OTTOLINE and embraces her .My dear child !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: In rather a strained voice .Sir Timothy Barradell is here , Dad .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: I heard he had called .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: So sweet of him to treat us informally !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: To LADY FILSON .He would like to see you and Dad for a minute or two , mother ——

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Charmed !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Delighted !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Just to — just to bid you good-bye .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Good-bye ?

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Good-bye ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Yes ; he 's going away — abroad — for some months .With a motion of her head towards the hall .He 's in the hall . May I ——?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Rising .Er — do .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Do .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Returning to the door and calling .Sir Timothy ——!

div.stage: There is a brief pause , during which SIR RANDLE and LADY FILSON interrogate each other silently , and then SIR TIMOTHY BARRADELL enters . He is a well-knit , pleasant-looking Irishman of about forty , speaking with a slight brogue .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Advancing to greet him .My dear Sir Timothy !

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: As they shake hands .And how 's my lady this morning ? Are you well ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: At the door .I 'll leave you ——

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Turning to her hastily .Ah —!Taking her hand .I 'm not to see you again ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Shaking her head .No .Smiling .We 've said good-bye upstairs .Withdrawing her hand .Que Dieu vous protège ! Good luck to you !

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Ruefully .Luck !In an undertone .I 've never had anything else till now ; and now it 's out entirely .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Gently .Shsssh ——!

div.stage: She goes into the hall and he stands watching her till she disappears . Then he closes the door and faces LADY FILSON and SIR RANDLE .

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Mournfully but good-humouredly .Ha ! That 's over .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Over ?

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Over ?

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Over .Passing LADY FILSON and shaking hands with SIR RANDLE .It might be that it ‘ ud be more decent and appropriate for me to write you a letter , Sir Randle ; but I 'm not much of a hand at letter-writing , and I 've your daughter 's permission to tell you by word of mouth that — that she —to LADY FILSONbut perhaps you can guess , both of you ——?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Guess ——?

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Guess ——?

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Rumpling his hair .The fact is , it is n't exactly easy or agreeable to describe what 's occurred in plain terms .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Encouragingly .Ca n't you — can n't you give us a hint ——?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: The merest hint ——

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Hint , is it ! Ah , I can manage that .With a bold effort .You 're not to have me for your son-in-law . Is that hint enough ?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Under her breath .Oh !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: God bless me ! Frankly , I had no conception ——

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Nor I — the faintest .

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: And as I 've received a great deal of kindness and hospitality in this house , I thought that , in common gratitude , I ought to explain the cause of my abrupt disappearance from your circle .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: In a tone of deep commiseration .I — I understand . You — you intend to ——?

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: To take a trip round the world , to endeavour to recover some of the wind that 's been knocked out of me .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Closing his eyes .Distressing ! Distressing !

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Most .Coming to SIR TIMOTHY , feelingly .Oh — oh , Sir Timothy ——!

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: With sudden bitterness .Ah , Sir Timothy , Sir Timothy , Sir Timothy ! And what 's the use of my baronetcy now , will you inform me — the baronetcy I bought and paid for , in hard cash , to better my footing in society ? The mockery of it ! Now that I 've lost her , the one woman I shall ever love , I do n't care a rap for my footing in society ;walking awayand anybody may have my baronetcy for tuppence !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Reprovingly .My good friend ——!

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Turning to SIR RANDLE and LADY FILSON .And why not ! The only advantage of my baronetcy , it strikes me , is that I 'm charged double prices at every hotel I lay my head in , and am expected to shower gold on the waiters .Sitting on the settee on the right and leaning his head on his hand .Oh , the mockery of it ; the mockery of it !

lg.l: If my profound sympathy — and Lady Filson 's —
I may speak for you , Winnie ——?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Certainly .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: To SIR TIMOTHY .If our profound sympathy is the smallest consolation to you ——

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Emphatically , raising his head .It is not .With a despairing gesture .I 'm broken-hearted , Sir Randle . That 's what I am ; I 'm broken-hearted .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Sitting in the low-backed arm-chair on the left .Oh , dear !
