sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Sighing .If I 'd had the pluck to declare myself sooner , it might have been different .Staring before him .From the moment I first set eyes on her , at the dinner-party you gave to welcome her on her arrival in London — from that moment I was captured completely , body and soul . The sight of her as she stood in the drawing-room beside her mother , with her pretty , white face and her elegant figure , and a gown clinging to her that looked as though she 'd been born in it — ‘ twill never fade from me if I live to be as old as a dozen Methuselahs !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Pryingly .Er — has Ottoline — I have no desire to probe an open wound — has she assigned any — reason ——?

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Rousing himself .For rejecting me ?

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: With a wave of the hand .For ——

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: For not seeing her way clear ——

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: To — er — in short — accept you ?

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: She has .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Has she !

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: The best — and , for me , the worst — of reasons . There 's another man in the case .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Another ——?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Another ——!

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: To LADY FILSON .Extraordinary !

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Bewildering .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: We have been blind , Winnie .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Absolutely .

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: And , whoever he may be , I trust he 'll worship her as devoutly as I do , and treat her with half the gentleness I 'd have treated her with , had she selected me for her Number Two .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Piously .Amen !To LADY FILSON .Winifred ——?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Rather fretfully .Amen .

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Rising .And with that sentiment on my lips , and in every fibre of my body , I 'll relieve you of my depressing company .Going to LADY FILSON , who rises at his approach , and taking her hand .My dear lady ——

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Genuinely .My dear Sir Timothy !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Moving to the glazed door .Painful ! Painful !

div.stage: As SIR TIMOTHY turns from LADY FILSON , BERTRAM reappears , in morning-dress , entering from the hall .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Drawing back on seeing SIR TIMOTHY .Oh !To SIR RANDLE .Am I intruding ?

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Come in , my boy . You 're just in time to give a parting grasp of the hand to our friend here .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Advancing to SIR TIMOTHY , surprised .Parting ——?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: To BERTRAM .Sir Timothy is going abroad , Bertram .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Really ?To SIR TIMOTHY .Er — on business ?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Puzzled .Good-bye .SIR TIMOTHY makes a final bow to LADY FILSON and departs , followed by SIR RANDLE , who leaves the door open . BERTRAM turns to LADY FILSON inquiringly .What ——?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Pointing to the open door .H'sh !

div.stage: BERTRAM shuts the door and LADY FILSON seats herself upon the settee on the right .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Coming to her .What has happened , mother ?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: What I conjectured . I was certain of it .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: He has proposed to my sister ?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Struck by his mother 's manner .She has refused him ?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Nodding .She 's éprise with another man .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Who is it ?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: She did n't ——

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Is it Trefusis ?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: I believe it 's Delacour .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Walking about .Possibly ! Possibly !

lg.l: I do hope she realizes what she 's doing , Bertram . Sir
Timothy could buy them both up , with something to spare .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: I agree , my dear mother ; but it would have been horribly offensive to us , I mean t'say , to see the name of Ottoline 's husband branded upon sides of bacon in the windows of the provision-shops .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Oh , disgusting !Brightening .How sensibly you look at things , darling !

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Taking up a position before the fireplace .Whereas George Delacour and Edward Trefusis are undeniably gentlemen — gentlemen by birth and breeding , I mean t'say .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Trefusis is connected , through his brother , with the Northcrofts !

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Quite so . If Ottoline married Edward , she would be Lady Juliet 's sister-in-law .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Upon my word , Bertie , I do n't know which of the two I 'd rather it turned out to be !

div.stage: SIR RANDLE returns , with a solemn countenance . He closes the door and comes forward .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: To LADY FILSON .A melancholy morning , Winnie .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Sighing .Ahhh !

lg.stage: Producing a black-edged pocket-handkerchief and unfolding it .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: I 've told him .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: My dear father , I cannot — I cannot profess to regret my sister 's decision . I mean to say ——!

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Suddenly .Nor I .In an outburst , pacing the room .Nor I. I must be candid . It 's my nature to be candid . A damned tradesman !

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Exactly . It shows my sister 's delicacy and refinement , I mean t'say .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: To LADY FILSON , halting .Who , in your opinion , Winnie ——?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: I 'm inclined to think it 's Mr. Delacour .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Resuming his walk .So be it .Raising his arms .If I am to lose my child a second time — so be it .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: I venture to suggest it may be Edward Trefusis .

lg.l: My dear boy , in a matter of this kind ,
I fancy we can rely on your mother 's wonderful powers of penetration .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Bowing .Pardon , father .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Closing her eyes .“ Mrs. George Delacour . ”

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Partly closing his eyes and again resuming his walk .“ A marriage is arranged and will shortly take place between George Holmby Delacour , of — of — of —— ”

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Closing his eyes .“ 90 , St. James 's Street —— ”

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Opening her eyes .What is that , Randle ?

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Ottoline being a widow , there can be no bridesmaids ; which deprives us of the happiness of paying a pretty compliment to the daughters of several families of distinction whom we have the privilege of numbering among our acquaintances .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: There can be no bridesmaids , strictly speaking ; but a widow may be accompanied to the altar by a bevy of Maids of Honour .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Ah , yes ! An equally good opportunity for an imposing —closing his eyesand reverential display !To LADY FILSON .Lady Maundrell 's girl Sybil , eh , Winnie ?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Decidedly . And Lady Eva Sherringham .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Lady Lilian and Lady Constance Foxe ——

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Lady Irene Pallant ——

div.stage: LADY FILSON rises and almost runs to the writing-table , where she sits and snatches at a sheet of paper . SIR RANDLE follows her and stands beside her .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Reclining upon the settee on the left .Lady Blanche Finnis ——

lg.l: Wait ; do n't be so quick !

div.stage: The glazed door is opened softly and OTTOLINE enters . She pauses , looking at the group at the writing-table .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: To LADY FILSON , as she writes .Lady Eva Sherringham ——

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Ladies Lilian and Constance Foxe ——

lg.l: “ Lady Eva Sherringham — Ladies Lilian and Constance

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Lady Irene Pallant ——

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: I pray there may be no captious opposition from Ottoline .

lg.l: Surely she does n't want to be married like a middle-class widow from

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: If pages are permissible — to carry my sister 's train , I mean t'say ——

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Pages — yes , yes ——

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: There are the two Galbraith boys — little Lord Wensleydale and his brother Herbert .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Writing .Such picturesque children !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: I doubt whether the bare civilities which have passed between ourselves and Lord and Lady Galbraith ——

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: They are country neighbours .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: No harm in approaching them , my dear father . I mean to say ——!

div.stage: OTTOLINE shuts the door with a click . SIR RANDLE and LADY FILSON turn , startled , and LADY FILSON slips the list into a drawer .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Benignly .Otto ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: In a steady voice .Sorry to disturb you all over your elaborate preparations , Dad . I see Sir Timothy has saved me the trouble of breaking the news .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Y-you ——?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Nodding .You were too absorbed . I could n't help listening .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Ahem ! Sir Timothy did n't volunteer the information , Ottoline ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Peu m'importe !Advancing , smiling on one side of her mouth .What a grand wedding you are planning for me ! Quel projets mirifiques !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Embarrassed .Your dear mother was — er — merely jotting down ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Passing her hands over her face and walking to the settee on the right .Ha , ha , ha , ha ——!

lg.stage: Rising and moving to the fireplace , complainingly .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Sitting upon the settee .Ha , ha , ha ——!

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: To BERTRAM , who is slowly getting to his feet .Go away , Bertie darling .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Mais pourquoi ? Bertie knows everything , obviously .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Why should n't he , Otto ? Your brother is as interested as we are ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: But of course ! Naturellement !With a shrug .C'est une affaire de famille .To BERTRAM , who is now at the door on the left , his hand on the door-handle .Come back , Bertie .Repeating her wry smile .I shall be glad to receive your congratulations with mother 's and Dad 's .To SIR RANDLE and LADY FILSON .Sit down , Dad ; sit down , mother .SIR RANDLE sits in the chair on the left of the settee on the right , LADY FILSON in the low-backed arm-chair , and BERTRAM at the oblong table .Are you very much surprised , dear people ?

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Surprised ? Hardly .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Poor Sir Timothy ! No , we are hardly surprised , Ottoline .

lg.l: Ah , but I do n't mean surprised at my — having made Sir Timothy unhappy ;
I mean surprised at hearing there is — someone else ——

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: My dear child , that surprises us even less .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Your dear father and I , Ottoline , are not unaware of the many eligible men who are — how shall I put it ?— pursuing you with their attentions .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Parents are notoriously short-sighted ; but they are not necessarily — er — what are the things ?— tssh !— the creatures that flutter ——

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Bats , father .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: To BERTRAM .Thank you , my boy .

lg.l: It 's cowardly of me perhaps , but I almost wish
I had told Sir Timothy — a little more ——

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Cowardly ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: So that he might have taken the edge off the announcement I 'm going to make — and spared me ——

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: The edge ——?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Spared you —?Staring at OTTOLINE .Ottoline , what on earth ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Relaxing .Oh , I know I 'm behaving as if I were a girl instead of a woman who has been married — a widow — free — independent —to SIR RANDLEthanks to your liberality , Dad ! But , being at home , I seem to have lost , in a measure , my sense of personal liberty ——

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Blandly but uneasily .My child !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: That 's it ! Child ! Now that I 've returned to you , I 'm still a child — still an object for you to fix your hopes and expectations upon . The situation has slipped back , in your minds , pretty much to what it was in the old days in the Avenue Montaigne . You may protest that it is n't so , but it is .Attempting a laugh .That 's why my knees are shaking at this moment , and my spine 's all of a jelly !She rises and goes to the chair at the writing-table and grips the chair-rail . The others follow her apprehensively with their eyes .I — I 'm afraid I 'm about to disappoint you .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: H-how ?

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Disap-point us ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Abruptly .What 's the time , Dad ?

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Looking at a clock standing on a commode against the wall on the right .Twenty minutes past eleven .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: He — he will be here at half-past . Do n't be angry . I 've asked him to come — to explain his position clearly to you and mother with regard to me . There 's to be nothing underhand — rien de secret !

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: A-asked whom ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Throwing her head back .Ho ! You 'll think I 'm ushering in an endless string of lovers this morning ! I promise you this is the last .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Who is coming ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Sitting at the writing-table and , her elbows on the table , supporting her chin on her fists .Mr. Mackworth .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: After a pause .Mackworth ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Philip Mackworth .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Dully .Is n't he the journalist man you — you carried on with once , in Paris ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: What an expression , mother ! Well — yes .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Simply .Good God !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: He does n't write for the papers any longer .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: W-what ——?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: A novelist chiefly .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Faintly .Oh !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Successful ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: It depends on what you call success .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: I call success what everybody calls success .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Rising , stricken .There are novelists and novelists , I mean t'say .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Do n't imagine that I am apologizing for him , please , in the slightest degree ; but no , he has n't been successful up to the present , in the usual acceptation of the term .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Searching for her handkerchief .Where — where have you ——?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: I met him yesterday at Robbie Roope 's , at lunch .LADY FILSON finds her handkerchief and applies it to her eyes .Oh , there 's no need to cry , mother dear . For mercy 's sake ——!

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Oh , Otto !Rising and crossing to the settee on the right , whimpering .Oh , Randle !To BERTRAM , who comes to her .Oh , my boy !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Gazing blinkingly at the ceiling as LADY FILSON sinks upon the settee .Incredible ! Incredible !

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Sitting beside LADY FILSON , dazed .My dear mother ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Starting up .Oh , do try to be understanding and sympathetic ! Mr. Mackworth is a high-souled , noble fellow . If I 'd been honest with myself , I should have married him ten years ago . To me this is a golden dream come true . Recollect my bitter experience of the other sort of marriage !Walking away to the fireplace .Why grudge me a spark of romance in my life !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Raising his hands .Romance !

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: To SIR RANDLE and BERTRAM .Just now she was resenting our considering her a child !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Looking down upon the flowers in the grate .Romance does n't belong to youth , mother . Youth is greedy for reality — the toy that feels solid in its fingers . I was , and bruised myself with it . After such a lesson as I 've had , one yearns for something less tangible — something that lifts one morally out of oneself — an ideal ——!

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Ha ! An extract from a novel of Mr. Mackworth 's apparently !

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Harshly .Ha , ha , ha , ha ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Turning sharply and coming forward .Sssh ! Do n't you sneer , mother ! Do n't you sneer , Dad !Her eyes flashing .C'est auhYpppHeNdessus de vous de sentir ce qu'il y a d'élevé et de grand !Fiercely .Tenez ! Qu'il vous plaise ou non ——!

div.stage: She is checked by the entrance of UNDERWOOD from the hall .

sp.speaker: UNDERWOOD
sp.p: Addressing the back of LADY FILSON 's head .Mr. Philip Mackworth , m'lady .

sp.speaker: UNDERWOOD
sp.p: I beg pardon , m'lady . The gentleman inquired for your ladyship ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: To UNDERWOOD .In the drawing-room —with a queenly airno , in my own room .

sp.speaker: UNDERWOOD
sp.p: To OTTOLINE .Yes , mad 'm .

div.stage: UNDERWOOD withdraws .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Approaching SIR RANDLE and LADY FILSON .Dad — mother ——?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Your father may do as he chooses .Rising and crossing to the writing-table , where she sits and prepares to write .I have letters to answer .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: To SIR RANDLE .Dad ——?

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Rising .Impossible — impossible .Marching to the fireplace .I cannot act apart from your dear mother .His back to the fireplace , virtuously .I never act apart from your dear mother .

lg.stage: Moving to the glazed door and there pausing .

div.stage: SIR RANDLE blinks at the ceiling again . LADY FILSON scribbles audibly with a scratchy pen . OTTOLINE goes out , closing the door .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Jumping up as the door shuts — in an expostulatory tone .Good heavens ! My dear father — my dear mother ——!

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Coming to earth .Eh ?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Agitatedly .My sister will pack her trunks and be off to an hotel if you 're not careful . She wo n't stand this , I mean t'say . There 'll be a marriage at the registrar 's , or some ghastly proceeding — a scandal — all kinds of gossip ——!

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Throwing down her pen and rising — holding her heart .Oh ——!

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: With energy .I mean to say ——!

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: To LADY FILSON , blankly .Winnie ——?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: R-Randle ——?

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Biting his nails .He 's right .BERTRAM hastens to the glazed door .Dear Bertram is right .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Opening the door .You 'll see him ——?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Y-yes .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Yes .BERTRAM disappears . SIR RANDLE paces the room at the back , waving his arms .Oh ! Oh !

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Going to the fireplace .I wo n't be civil to him , Randle ! The impertinence of his visit ! I wo n't be civil to him !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: A calamity ! An unmerited calamity !

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Dropping on to the settee before the fireplace .She 's mad ! That 's the only excuse I can make for her !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Stark mad ! A calamity .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: You remember the man ?

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Taking a book from the rack on the oblong table and hurriedly turning its pages .A supercilious , patronizing person — son of a wretched country parson — used to loll against the wall of your salon — with his nose in the air .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Tearfully .A stroke of bad fortune at last , Randle ! Fancy ! Everything has always gone so well with us ——!

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Suddenly , groaning .Oh !

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Over her shoulder .What is it ? I can n't bear much more ——

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: He is n't even in Who 's Who , Winnie !

div.stage: BERTRAM returns , out of breath .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: I caught her on the stairs .Closing the door .She 'll bring him down .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Weakly .I wo n't be civil to him . I refuse to be civil to him .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Replacing the book in the rack and sitting in the chair at the oblong table — groaning again .Oh !

div.stage: There is a short silence . BERTRAM slowly advances .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Heavily , drawing his hand across his brow .Of course , my dear father — my dear mother — we must do our utmost to quash it — strain every nerve , I mean t'say , to stop my sister from committing this stupendous act of folly .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Rocking herself to and fro .Oh ! Oh !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: A beggarly author !

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: The picture of dejection .But if the worst comes to the worst — if she 's obdurate , I mean t'say — an alliance between Society and Literature — I suppose there 's no actual disgrace in it .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: A duffer — a duffer whose trash does n't sell ——!

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Taking advantage of a silly , emotional woman , to feather his nest !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Rising and pacing up and down between the glazed door and the settee on the right .I shall have difficulty —shaking his uplifted fistI shall have difficulty in restraining myself from denouncing Mr. Mackworth in her presence !

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Dismally .As to the wedding , there 's no reason that I can see — because a lady marries a literary man , I mean t'say — why the function should be a shabby one .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Rising and moving about at the back distractedly .That it sha'n ' t be ! If we can n't prevent my poor girl from throwing herself away , I 'm determined her wedding shall be smart and impressive !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Bitterly , with wild gestures .“ The interesting engagement is announced of Mr .— Mr .—— ”

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Wandering to the fireplace , his chin on his breast .Philip , father .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: “ — Mr. Philip Mackworth , the well-known novelist , to Ottoline , widow of the late Comte de Chaumié —peeping into the hall through the side of one of the curtains of the glazed door — his voice dying to a mutteronly daughter of Sir Randle and Lady Filson —— ”

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: “ Mrs .— Philip — Mackworth ” ! Ha , ha , ha ! Mrs. Philip Nobody !

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Joining her .Perhaps it would be wiser , mother , for me to retire while the interview takes place .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Falling upon his neck .Oh , my dear boy ——!

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Getting away from the door .They 're coming !

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Quickly .I 'm near you if you want me , I mean t'say ——

div.stage: He goes out at the door on the left . LADY FILSON hastily resumes her seat at the writing-table , and SIR RANDLE , pulling himself together , crosses to the fireplace . The glazed door opens and OTTOLINE appears with PHILIP .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Quietly .Mr. Mackworth , mother — Dad ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Advancing to LADY FILSON cordially .How do you do , Lady Filson ?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Giving him a reluctant hand and eyeing him askance with mingled aversion and indignation .H-how do you do ?

lg.l: This is very good of you .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: His head in the air , severely .How do you do , Mr. Mackworth ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Breaking the ice .We — we meet after many years ——

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Many .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Still examining PHILIP .M-many .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: And — if you 've ever bestowed a thought on me since the old Paris days — in a way you can scarcely have expected .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Turning to the writing-table to conceal her repugnance .Scarcely .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Scarcely .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: To SIR RANDLE .Oh , I am not vain enough , Sir Randle , to flatter myself that what you have heard from Ottoline gives you and Lady Filson unmixed pleasure . On the contrary ——

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Gulping .Pleasure !Unable to repress herself .Unmixed —! Ho , ho , ho , ho ——!

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Restraining her .Winifred ——!

lg.stage: Coming to LADY FILSON and touching her gently — in a low voice .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Smiling at OTTOLINE apologetically .It 's my fault ; I provoked that .Walking away to the right .I expressed myself rather clumsily , I 'm afraid .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Expanding his chest and advancing to PHILIP .I gather from my daughter , Mr. Mackworth , that you are here for the purpose of “ explaining your position ” in relation to her . I believe I quote her words accurately ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Moving to the fireplace .Yes , Dad .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: That is so , Sir Randle — if you and Lady Filson will have the patience ——

div.stage: SIR RANDLE motions PHILIP to the settee on the right . PHILIP sits . Then OTTOLINE sits on the settee before the fireplace , and SIR RANDLE in the arm-chair by PHILIP . LADY FILSON turns in her chair to listen .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: To PHILIP , majestically .Before you embark upon your explanation , permit me to define my position — mine and Lady Filson 's .PHILIP nods .I am going to make a confession to you ; and I should like to feel that I am making it as one gentleman to another .PHILIP nods again .Mr. Mackworth , Lady Filson and I are ambitious people . Not for ourselves . For ourselves , all we desire is rest and retirement —closing his eyesif it were possible , obscurity . But where our children are concerned , it is different ; and , to be frank — I must be frank — we had hoped that , in the event of Ottoline remarrying , she would contract such a marriage as is commonly described as brilliant .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Dryly .Such a marriage as her marriage to Monsieur de Chaumié , for example .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Closing his eyes .De mortuis , Mr. Mackworth ! I must decline ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: I merely wished , as a basis of argument , to get at your exact interpretation of brilliancy .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Dismissing the point with a wave of the hand .It is easy for you , therefore , as you have already intimated , to judge what are our sensations at receiving my daughter 's communication .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Nodding .They are distinctly disagreeable .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Conscientiously .They are — I wo n't exaggerate — I must n't exaggerate — they are not far removed from dismay .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Utter dismay .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Shifting his chair — to PHILIP .I learn — I learn from Ottoline that you have forsaken the field of journalism , Mr. Mackworth , and now devote yourself exclusively to creative work ?Another nod from PHILIP .But you have not — to use my daughter 's phrase — up to the present — er ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Nursing his leg .Please go on .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: You have not been eminently successful ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Not yet . Not with the wide public . No ; not yet .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Forgive me — any private resources ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: None worth mentioning . Two-hundred-a-year , left me by an old aunt .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Under her breath .Ho ——!

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: To her .My dear ——!To PHILIP .On the other hand , Mr. Mackworth , as you are probably aware , my daughter is — no , I wo n't say a rich woman — I will say comfortably provided for ; not by the late Comte de Chaumié , but by myself .Closing his eyes .I have never been a niggardly parent , Mr. Mackworth .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Softly , without turning .Indeed , no , Dad !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: To SIR RANDLE , bluntly .Yes , I do know of the settlement you made upon Ottoline on her marriage , and of your having supplemented it when she became a widow . Very handsome of you .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: As before .Ha !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Leaning back in his chair .There then , my dear Mr. Mackworth , is the state of the case . Ottoline is beyond our control ——

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Unhappily .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: If she will deal this crushing blow to her mother and myself , we must bow our heads to it . But , for the sake of your self-esteem , I beg you to reflect !Partly to PHILIP , partly at OTTOLINE .What construction would be put upon a union between you and Madame de Chaumié — between a lady of means and — I must be cruel — I must be brutal — a man who is — commercially at least — a failure ?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: There could only be one construction put upon it !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Rising .Mother ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: To SIR RANDLE , calmly .Oh , but — ah , Ottoline has n't told you ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: To PHILIP .No , I had n't time , Philip ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: My dear Sir Randle —rising and going to LADY FILSON— my dear Lady Filson — let me dispel your anxiety for the preservation of my self-esteem . Ottoline and I have no idea of getting married yet awhile .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: No , mother .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: When , pray ——?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: We have agreed to wait until I have ceased to be — commercially — a failure .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: To SIR RANDLE and LADY FILSON .Until he has obtained public recognition ;coming forwarduntil , in fact , even the member 's of one 's own family , Dad , can n't impute unworthy motives .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: To PHILIP , incredulously — rising .Until you have obtained public recognition , Mr. Mackworth ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Smiling .Well , it may sound extravagant ——

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Grotesque !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Walking about on the extreme right .Amazing !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Why grotesque ; why amazing ?Sitting in the low-backed arm-chair .All that is amazing about it is that Philip should lack the superior courage which enables a man , in special circumstances , to sink his pride and ignore ill-natured comments .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: To LADY FILSON .At any rate , this is the arrangement that Ottoline and I have entered into ; and I suggest , with every respect , that you and Sir Randle should raise no obstacle to my seeing her under your roof occasionally .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: As being preferable to hole-and-corner meetings in friends ’ houses ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Coolly .Or under lamp-posts in the streets — yes , mother .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Rising and crossing to the round table .Ottoline ——!

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Bearing down upon PHILIP .May I ask , Mr. Mackworth , how long you have been following your precarious profession ? Pardon my ignorance . My reading is confined to our great journals ; and there your name has escaped me .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Oh , I 've been at it for nearly ten years .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Ten years !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: To SIR RANDLE .I began soon after I left Paris .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: And what ground , sir , have you for anticipating that you will ever achieve popularity as a writer ?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Sitting in the chair by the round table .Preposterous !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Stamping her foot .Mother ——!To SIR RANDLE .Philip has high expectations of his next novel , Dad . It is to be published in the autumn — September .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: To PHILIP .And should that prove no more successful with the “ wide public ” than those which have preceded it ——?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Then I — then I fling another at ‘ em .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Which would occupy you ——?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Twelve months .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: And if that fails ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Smiling again , but rather constrainedly .Ah , you travel too quickly for me , Lady Filson — you and Sir Randle ! You heap disaster on disaster ——

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: If that fails , another twelve-months ’ labour !

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: While my daughter is wasting the best years of her life !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Indignantly .Really , Mr. Mackworth !Throwing himself upon the settee on the right .Really ! I appeal to you ! Is this fair ?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Is it fair to Ottoline ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Absolument ! So that it satisfies me to spend the best years of my life in this manner , I do n't see what anybody has to complain of . Mon Dieu ! I am relieved to think that some of my best years are still mine to squander !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: To PHILIP , who is standing by the writing-table in thought , a look of disquiet on his face — persistently .Mr. Mackworth ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Rising impatiently .My dear Dad — my dear mother — I propose that we postpone this discussion until Mr. Mackworth 's new book has failed to attract the public ,crossing to SIR RANDLEand that in the meantime he sha'n ' t be scowled at when he presents himself in Ennismore Gardens .Seating herself beside SIR RANDLE and slipping her arm through his .Dad ——!

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: To PHILIP .Mr. Mackworth ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Rousing himself and turning to SIR RANDLE and LADY FILSON — abruptly .Look here , Sir Randle ! Look here , Lady Filson ! I own that this arrangement between Ottoline and me is an odd one . It was arrived at yesterday impulsively ; and , in her interests , there is a good deal to be said against it .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: There 's nothing to be said for it . Oh ——!

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: To LADY FILSON .Winifred —To PHILIP .Well , Mr. Mackworth ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Well , Sir Randle , I — I 'm prepared to take a sporting chance . It may be that I am misled by the sanguine temperament of the artist , who is apt to believe that his latest production will shake the earth to its foundation . I 've gammoned myself before into such a belief , but —resolutelyI 'll stake everything on my next book ! I give you my word that if it is n't a success — an indisputable popular success — I will join you both , in all sincerity , in urging Ottoline to break with me . Come ! Does that mollify you ?

div.stage: There is a short silence . SIR RANDLE and LADY FILSON look at each other in surprise and OTTOLINE stares at PHILIP open-mouthed .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Philip ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: To SIR RANDLE .Sir Randle ——?

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: To LADY FILSON .Winnie ——?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: In a softer tone .It certainly seems to me that Mr. Mackworth 's undertaking — as far as it goes ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: With a queer laugh .Ha , ha , ha ! As far as it goes , mother !Rising , thoughtfully .Does n't it go a little too far ?Contracting her brows .It disposes of me as if I were of no more account than a sawdust doll !To PHILIP .Ah , traitor !In a low voice .Vos promesses à une femme sont sans valeur !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Taking her hands reassuringly .No , no ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Withdrawing her hands .Zut !Moving slowly towards the glazed door .You have acquitted yourself bravely , mon cher Monsieur Philippe !Shrugging her shoulders .Say good-bye and let me turn you out in disgrace .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Deprecatingly .Ha , ha , ha !Going to LADY FILSON .Good-bye , Lady Filson .She rises and shakes hands with him .Have I bought my right of entrée ? I may ring your bell at discreet intervals till the end of the season ?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Stiffly .Ottoline is her own mistress , Mr. Mackworth ;more amiablybut apart from her , you will receive a card from me — music — Tuesday , July the eighth .

div.stage: He bows and she crosses to the fireplace . Then he shakes hands with SIR RANDLE , who has risen and is standing in the middle of the room .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: To SIR RANDLE .Good-bye .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Detaining PHILIP , searchingly .Er — pardon me — this new novel of yours , on which you place so much reliance — pray do n't think me curious ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Suddenly .Ha !Coming to the back of the settee on the right , her eyes gleaming scornfully at SIR RANDLE .Tell my father , Philip — tell him ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Shaking his head at her and frowning .Otto ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Do ; as you told it to me yesterday .Satirically .It will help him to understand why your name has escaped him in the great journals !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Any confidence you may repose in me , Mr. Mackworth ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Prompting PHILIP .It 's called — allons ! racontez donc !——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: After a further look of protest at OTTOLINE — to SIR RANDLE , hesitatingly .It 's called “ The Big Drum , ” Sir Randle .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: No ; social .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Social ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Leaning against the arm-chair on the left of the settee on the right .It 's an attempt to portray the struggle for notoriety — for self-advertisement — we see going on around us to-day .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Ah , yes ; lamentable !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Deliberately , but losing himself in his subject as he proceeds .It shows a vast crowd of men and women , sir , forcing themselves upon public attention without a shred of modesty , fighting to obtain it as if they are fighting for bread and meat . It shows how dignity and reserve have been cast aside as virtues that are antiquated and outworn , until half the world — the world that should be orderly , harmonious , beautiful — has become an arena for the exhibition of vulgar ostentation or almost superhuman egoism — a cockpit resounding with raucous voices bellowing one against the other !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Closing his eyes .A terrible picture !

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Closing her eyes .Terrible .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: It shows the bishop and the judge playing to the gallery , the politician adopting the methods of the cheap-jack , the duchess vying with the puffing draper ; it shows how even true genius submits itself to conditions that are accepted and excused as “ modern , ” and is found elbowing and pushing in the hurly-burly . It shows how the ordinary decencies of life are sacrificed to the paragraphist , the interviewer , and the ghoul with the camera ; how the home is stripped of its sanctity , blessed charity made a vehicle for display , the very grave-yard transformed into a parade ground ; while the outsider looks on with a sinking of the vitals because the drumstick is beyond his reach and the bom-bom-bom is not for him ! It shows ——!Checking himself and leaving the arm-chair with a short laugh .Oh , well , that 's the setting of my story , Sir Randle ! I wo n't inflict the details upon you .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Er — h 'm —expansivelyan excellent theme , Mr. Mackworth ; a most promising theme !To LADY FILSON .Eh , Winifred ?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Politely .Excellent ; quite , quite excellent !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Bowing to LADY FILSON and going to OTTOLINE .Thank you .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: To PHILIP , glowingly .Splendid !Laying her hand upon his arm .You have purged your disgrace .Softly .You may come and see me to-morrow .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: To OTTOLINE .Ha , ha ——!

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: In response to a final bow from PHILIP .Good-bye .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Good-bye .

div.stage: OTTOLINE opens the glazed door and PHILIP follows her into the hall . Immediately the door is shut , LADY FILSON hurries to SIR RANDLE .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: In high spirits .Winnie ——!

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: That will never be a popular success , Randle !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Never . An offensive book ——!

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Ho , ho , ho , ho ——!

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: A grossly offensive book !

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Anxiously .He — he 'll keep his word ——?

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: To join us in persuading her to drop him ——

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: If it fails ?

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: With conviction .Yes .Walking about .Yes . We must be just . We owe it to ourselves to be just to Mr. Mackworth . He is not altogether devoid of gentlemanlike scruples .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Breathlessly .And — and she ——?

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: I trust — I trust that my child 's monstrous infatuation will have cooled down by the autumn .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Supporting herself by the chair at the writing-table , her hand to her heart — exhausted .Oh ! Oh , dear !

lg.l: I conducted the affair with skill and tact ,

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Rallying .It was masterly —kissing himmasterly ——

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Proudly .Ha !

div.stage: She sits at the writing-table again and takes up her pen as SIR RANDLE stalks to the door on the left .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Masterly !

lg.stage: He disappears . LADY FILSON scribbles violently .

div.head: THE THIRD ACT

stage.stage: The scene represents two rooms , connected by a pair of wide doors , in a set of residential chambers on the upper floor of a house in Gray 's Inn . The further room is the dining-room , the nearer room a study . In the wall at the back of the dining-room are two windows ; in the right-hand wall is a door leading to the kitchen ; and in the left-hand wall a door opens from a vestibule , where , opposite this door , there is another door which gives on to the landing of the common stair .

In the study , a door in the right-hand wall admits to a bedroom ; in the wall facing the spectator is a door opening into the room from the vestibule ; and beyond the door on the right , in a piece of wall cutting off the corner of the room , is the fireplace . A bright fire is burning .

The rooms are wainscotted to the ceilings and have a decrepit , old-world air , and the odds and ends of furniture — all characteristic of the dwelling of a poor literary man of refined taste — are in keeping with the surroundings . In the dining-room there are half-a-dozen chairs of various patterns , a sideboard or two , a corner-cupboard , a “ grandfather ” clock , and a large round table . In the study , set out into the room at the same angle as the fireplace , is a writing-table . A chair stands at the writing-table , its back to the fire , and in the front of the table is a well-worn settee . On the left of the settee is a smaller table , on which are an assortment of pipes , a box of cigars and another of cigarettes , a tobacco-jar , an ash-tray , and a bowl of matches ; and on the left of the table is a capacious arm-chair . There is an arm-chair on either side of the fireplace ; and against the right-hand wall , on the nearer side of the bedroom door , is a cabinet .

On the other side of the room , facing the bedroom door , there is a second settee , and behind the settee is an oblong table littered with books and magazines . At a little distance from this table stands an arm-chair , and against the wall at the back , on the left of the big doors , is a chair of a lighter sort . Also against the back wall , but on the left of the door opening from the vestibule , is a table with a telephone-instrument upon it , and running along the left-hand wall is a dwarf bookcase , unglazed , packed with books which look as if they would be none the worse for being dusted and put in order .
In the vestibule , against the wall on the right , there is a small table on which are Philip 's hats , caps , and gloves ; and an overcoat and a man 's cape are hanging on some pegs .

It is late on a November afternoon . Curtains are drawn across the dining-room windows , and the room is lighted rather dimly by an electric lamp standing upon a sideboard . A warm glow proceeds from the nearer right-hand corner as from a fire . The study is lighted by a couple of standard lamps and a library-lamp on the writing-table , and the vestibule by a lamp suspended from the ceiling .

[ PHILIP , a pipe in his mouth and wearing an old velvet jacket , is lying upon the settee on the right , reading a book by the light of the lamp on the writing-table . In the dining-room , JOHN and a waiter — the latter in his shirt-sleeves — are at the round table , unfolding a white table-cloth .

lg.stage: A cheery little man in seedy clothes — to the waiter , softly .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Raising his eyes from his book .What 's the time , John ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Quarter-to-six , sir .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Have my things come from the tailor 's yet ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Laying the cloth with the aid of the waiter .Yes , sir ; while you were dozing .Ecstatically .They 're lovely , sir .A bell rings in the vestibule .Expect that 's the cook , sir .He bustles into the vestibule from the dining-room . There is a short pause and then he reappears , entering the study at the door opening from the vestibule , followed by ROOPE .It 's Mr. Roope , sir !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: No !Throwing his book aside and jumping up .Why , Robbie !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: As they shake hands vigorously .My dear fellow !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Return of the wanderer ! When did you get back ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Last night .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Take your coat off , you old ruffian .Putting his pipe down .I am glad .

lg.stage: To JOHN , who relieves him of his hat , overcoat , and neckerchief .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Splendid , Mr. Roope .Beaming .Our new novel is sech a success , sir .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Ha , ha , ha , ha !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: To JOHN .So Mr. Mackworth wrote and told me .Giving his gloves to JOHN .Congratulate you , John .

lg.stage: Depositing the hat , coat , etc ., upon the settee on the left .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Crossing to the fireplace , rubbing his hands , as JOHN retires to the dining-room .Oh , my dear Phil , this dreadful climate after the sunshine of the Lago Maggiore !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Walking about and spouting , in high spirits .“ Italia ! O Italia ! thou who hast the fatal gift of beauty ——! ”

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Sir Loftus and Lady Glazebrook were moving on to Rome , or I really believe I could have endured another month at their villa , bores as they are , dear kind souls !Looking towards the dining-room , where JOHN and the waiter are now placing a handsome centre-piece of flowers upon the round table .Hallo ! A dinner-party , Phil ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Dinner-party ? A banquet !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: To celebrate the success of the book ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: That and something more . This festival , sir , of the preparations for which you are a privileged spectator —shouting to JOHNshut those doors , John ——

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Yessir .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Sitting in the chair on the left of the smoking-table as JOHN closes the big doors .This festival , my dear Robbie —glancing over his shoulder to assure himself that the doors are closedthis festival also celebrates my formal engagement to Madame de Chaumié .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Triumphantly .Aha !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Taking a cigarette from the box at his side .Ottoline and I are to be married soon after Christmas . The civilized world is to be startled by the announcement on Monday .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Advancing .My dear chap , I 've never heard anything that has given me greater pleasure .PHILIP offers ROOPE the cigarette-box .No , I wo n't smoke .Seating himself upon the settee on the right .When was it settled ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Lighting his cigarette .The day before yesterday . I got Titterton to write me a letter — Titterton , my publisher — certifying to the enormous sales of the book , and sent it on to Sir Randle Filson . Nothing like documentary evidence , Robbie .Leaning back in his chair with outstretched legs and exhaling a wreath of tobacco-smoke .Twenty-five thousand copies , my boy , up to date , and still going strong .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Wonderful .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Phew ! The critics treated me generously enough , but it hung fire damnably at first . At one particularly hellish moment I could have sworn it would n't do more than my usual fifteen or eighteen hundred , and I cursed myself for having been such a besotted fool as to pin my faith to it .Sitting upright .And then , suddenly , a rush — a tremendous rush ! Twenty-four thousand went off in less than six weeks . Almost uncanny , eh ?Touching the tobacco-jar .Oh , lord , sometimes I think I 've been putting opium into my pipe instead of this innocent baccy , and that I shall wake up to the necessity of counting my pence again and apologizing to John for being in arrear with his wages !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: And Titterton 's letter brought the Filsons round ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Nodding .Brought ‘ em round ; and I must say they 've accomplished the change of attitude most graciously .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Oracularly .Graciously or grudgingly , they could n't help themselves , dear excellent friend . As you had pledged yourself in effect to resign the lady if your book was a failure , it follows that they were bound to clasp you to their bosoms if it succeeded . I do n't want to detract from the amiability of the Filsons for an instant ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Anyhow , their opposition is at an end , and all is rosy .Rising and pacing the room .Master Bertram is a trifle glum and stand-offish perhaps , but Sir Randle —! Ha , ha , ha ! Sir Randle has taken Literature under his wing , Robbie , from Chaucer to Kipling , in the person of his prospective son-in-law . You 'd imagine , to listen to him , that to establish ties of relationship with a literary man has been his chief aim in life .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Jerking his head in the direction of the dining-room .And this is to be a family gathering ——?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: The first in the altered circumstances . I proposed a feast at a smart restaurant , but Sir Randle preferred the atmosphere which has conduced , as he puts it , to the creation of so many of my brilliant compositions .Behind the smoking-table , dropping the end of his cigarette into the ash-tray — gaily .Robbie , I 've had a magnificent suit of joy-rags made for the occasion !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Earnestly .Good ! I rejoice to hear it , dear excellent friend , and I hope it portends a wholesale order to your tailor and your intention to show yourself in society again freely .With a laugh , PHILIP goes to the fireplace and stands looking into the fire .Begin leaving your cards at once . No more sulking in your tent !Rising and crossing to the other side of the room .You have arrived , my dear chap ; I read your name in two papers in my cabin yesterday .Marching up and down .Your foot is on the ladder ; you bid fair to become a celebrity , if you are not one already ; and your approaching marriage sheds additional lustre on you . I envy you , Phil ; I do , positively .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Facing ROOPE .Oh , of course , I shall be seen about with Ottoline during our engagement . Afterwards ——

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Halting .Afterwards ——?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Everything will depend on my wife —relishing the wordmy wife . Ottoline has rather lost her taste for Society with a capital S , remember .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Testily .That was her mood last June , when she was hypped and discontented . With a husband she can be proud of , surely ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Coming forward .As a matter of fact , Robbie , I 'm inclined to agree with you ; I 've been staring into my fire , or out of my windows here , a jolly sight too much .Expanding his chest .It 'll be refreshing to me to rub shoulders with people again for a bit —smilingeven to find myself the object of a little interest and curiosity .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Delighted .Dear excellent friend !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Ha , ha ! You see , I 'm not without my share of petty vanity . I 'm consistent , though . Did n't I tell you in South Audley Street that I was as eager for fame as any man living , if only I could win it in my own way ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: You did .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Exultingly .Well , I have won it in my own way , have n't I !Hitting the palm of his hand with his fist .I 've done what I determined to do , Robbie ; what I knew I should do , sooner or later ! I 've got there — got there !— by simple , honest means ! Is n't it glorious ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Cautiously .I admit ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Breaking in .Oh , I do n't pretend that there have n't been moments in my years of stress and struggle when I 've been tempted to join the gaudy , cackling fowl whose feathers I flatter myself I 've plucked pretty thoroughly in my book ! But I 've resisted the devil by prayers and fasting ; and , by George , sir , I would n't swap my modest victory for the vogue of the biggest boomster in England !Boisterously .Ha , ha , ha ! Whoop !Seizing ROOPE and shaking him .Dare to preach your gospel to me now , you arch-apostle of quackery and self-advertisement !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Peevishly , releasing himself .Upon my word , Phil ——!

div.stage: The bell rings again .

lg.stage: To ROOPE , seeing that he is putting on his muffler .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: I must .Taking up his overcoat .I merely ran along to shake hands with you , and I 'm sorry I took the trouble .PHILIP helps him into his overcoat laughingly .Thanks .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Suddenly .Robbie ——!

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Struggling with an obstinate sleeve .Hey ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: It 's just struck me . Where are you dining to-night ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: At the Garrick , with Hughie Champion .Picking up his hat and gloves .He 's getting horribly deaf and tedious ; but I had nothing better .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Bother Colonel Champion ! I wish you could have dined with me .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: His hat on his head , drawing on his gloves .Dear excellent friend ! I should be out of place .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Rubbish ! Your presence would be peculiarly appropriate , my dear Robbie . Was n't it you who brought Ottoline and me together , God bless yer !Observing that ROOPE is weakening .There 's heaps of room for an extra chair . Everybody ‘ ud be delighted .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Meditatively .I could telephone to Hughie excusing myself . He did n't ask me till this afternoon .With an injured air .I resent a short notice .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: His eyes twinkling .Quite right . Mine 's short too ——

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: That 's different .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Entirely . You 'll come ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: If you 're certain the Filsons and Madame de Chaumié ——

lg.stage: Following ROOPE to the door admitting to the vestibule .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Opening the door .Charming .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Wo n't you let John fetch you a taxi ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Shaking hands with PHILIP .No , I 'll walk into Holborn .In the doorway .Oh , by-the-by , I 've a message for you , Phil .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: From whom ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Barradell , of all people in the world .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Surprised .Sir Timothy ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: He 's home . I crossed with him yesterday , and we travelled in the same carriage from Dover .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: What 's the message ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: He saw your book in my bag , and began talking about you . He said he had n't met you for years , but that I was to give you his warm regards .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Indeed ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Astutely .My impression is that he 's heard rumours concerning you and Madame de Chaumié while he 's been away , and that he 's anxious to show he has no ill-will . I suppose your calling so often in Ennismore Gardens has been remarked .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Extremely civil of him , if that 's the case .Loftily .Decent sort of fellow , I recollect .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Going into the vestibule .Very ; very .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Poor chap !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Opening the outer door .Eight o'clock , dear excellent friend .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: At his elbow .Sharp .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Disappearing .Au revoir !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Au revoir !Calling after ROOPE .Mind that corner !Closing the outer door with a bang and shouting .John !Coming back into the study .John !Closing the vestibule door .John !Going to the big doors and opening the one on the left a little way .John ——!

div.stage: OTTOLINE , richly dressed in furs , steps through the opening and confronts him . Her cheeks are flushed and her manner has lost some of its repose .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Shutting the door behind her as she enters — playfully .Qu'esthYpppHeNce que vous désirez John ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Catching her in his arms .My dear girl !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Ha , ha ! I 'm not going to stop a minute .Rapidly .I 've been to tea with Kitty Millington ; and as I was getting into my car , I suddenly thought —!He kisses her .I waited in there to avoid Robbie Roope .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Robbie came back yesterday . I hope I have n't done wrong ; I 've asked him to dine here to-night .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Wrong ! Dear old Robbie ! But I did n't want him just now .Loosening her wrap and hunting for a pocket in it .I 've brought you a little gift , Phil — en souvenir de cette soirée ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Reprovingly .Oh ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: I got it at Cartier 's this afternoon . I meant to slip it into your serviette to-night quietly , but it 's burning a hole in my pocket .She produces a small jewel-case and presents it to him .Will you wear that in your tie sometimes ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Opening the case and gazing at its contents .Phiou !She leaves him , walking away to the fireplace .What a gorgeous pearl !He follows her and they stand side by side , he holding the case at arm'shYpppHeNlength admiringly , his other arm round her waist .You should n't , Otto . You 're incorrigible .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Leaning her head against his shoulder — softly .Phil ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Still gazing at the scarf-pin .To-morrow I 'll buy the most beautiful silk scarf ever weaved .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Phil , I 've a feeling that it 's from to-night , when I sit at your table — how sweet your flowers are ; I could n't help noticing them !— I 've a feeling that it 's from to-night that we really belong to each other .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Pressing her closer to him .Ah ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: With a shiver , closing her eyes .What has gone before has been hateful — hateful !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Looking down upon her fondly .Hateful ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Until — until your book commenced to sell , at any rate . Suspense — a horrid sensation of uneasiness , mistrust — the fear that , through your foolish , hasty promise to mother and Dad , you might , after all , unite with them to cheat me out of my happiness ! That 's what it has been to me , Philip .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Rallying her , but a little guiltily .Ha , ha , ha ! You goose ! I knew exactly how events would shape , Otto ; had n't a doubt on the subject .Shutting the jewel-case with a snap and a flourish .I knew ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Releasing herself .Ah , yes , I dare say I 've been dreadfully stupid .Shaking herself , as if to rid herself of unpleasant memories , and again leaving him .Well ! Sans adieu !Fastening her wrap .Get your hat and take me downstairs .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Wait a moment !Chuckling .Ho , ho ! I 'm not to be outdone altogether .Pocketing her gift , he goes to the cabinet on the right and unlocks it . She watches him from the middle of the room . Presently he comes to her , carrying a little ring-case .Take off your glove —pointing to her left handthat one .She removes her glove tremulously . He takes a ring from the case , tosses the case on to the writing-table , and slips the ring on her third finger .By George , I 'm in luck ; blessed if it does n't fit !

div.stage: She surveys the ring in silence for a while ; then she puts her arms round his neck and hides her face on his breast .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Almost inaudibly .Oh , Phil !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Tenderly .And so this is the end of the journey , Otto !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: In a whisper .The end ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: The dreary journey in opposite directions you and I set out upon nearly eleven years ago in Paris .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Quivering .Ah ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: My dear , what does it matter as long as our roads meet at last , and meet where there are clear pools to bathe our vagabond feet and sunshine to heal our sore bodies !She raises her head and rummages for her handkerchief .Otto ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: In April — eh ——?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Drying her eyes .April ——?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: You have n't forgotten the compact we entered into at Robbie Roope 's ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Brightening .Ah , no !

lg.l: In April we walk under the chestnut-trees once more in the

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Smiling through her tears .And the Allée de Longchamp ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: As husband and wife — we shall be an old married couple by then ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Pulling on her glove .And drink milk at the d'Armenonville ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: And the Pré-Catelan ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: And we 'll make pilgrimages , Phil ——!

lg.l: Yes , we 'll gaze up at the windows of my gloomy lodgings in the Rue

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Contracting her brows .Quarante-trois bis .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Banteringly .Where you honoured me with a visit , madame , with your maid Nanette ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Warding off the recollection with a gesture .Oh , do n't ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Ha , ha , ha ! A shame of me ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Turning from him .Do get your hat and coat .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Going into the vestibule .Where 's your car ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Moving towards the vestibule .In South Square .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Returning to her , a cape over his shoulders , a soft hat on his head .Eight o'clock !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Eight o'clock .

div.stage: He takes her hands and they stand looking into each other 's eyes .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: After a pause .Fancy !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Faintly .Fancy !He is drawing her to him slowly when , uttering a low cry , she embraces him wildly and passionately .Oh !Clinging to him .Oh , Phil ! Oh — oh — oh ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Responding to her embrace .Otto — Otto ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Breaking from him .Oh ——!

div.stage: She hurries to the outer door . He follows her quickly , closing the vestibule door after him . Then the outer door is heard to shut , and the curtain falls . After a short interval , the curtain rises again , showing all the doors closed and the study in darkness save for the light of the fire . The bell rings , and again there is an interval ; and then the vestibule door is opened by JOHN — attired for waiting at table — and BERTRAM brushes past him and enters . BERTRAM is in evening dress .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: As he enters , brusquely .Yes , I know I 'm a little too soon . I want to speak to Mr. Mackworth — before the others come , I mean t'say ——

div.stage: JOHN switches on the light of a lamp by the vestibule door . It is now seen that BERTRAM is greatly flustered and excited .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Taking BERTRAM 's hat , overcoat , etc .I 'll tell Mr. Mackworth , sir . He 's dressin ’ .

div.stage: JOHN , eyeing BERTRAM wonderingly , goes to the door of the bedroom . There , having switched on the light of another lamp , he knocks .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: From the bedroom .Yes ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Opening the door a few inches .Mr. Filson , sir .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Calling out .Hallo , Bertram !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Mr. Filson wants to speak to you , sir .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: I 'll be with him in ten seconds . Leave the door open .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Yessir .

div.stage: JOHN withdraws , carrying BERTRAM 's outdoor things into the vestibule and shutting the vestibule door .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Calling to BERTRAM again .I 'm in the throes of tying a bow , old man . Sit down .BERTRAM , glaring at the bedroom door , remains standing .O'ho , that 's fine ! Ha , ha , ha ! I warn you , I 'm an overpowering swell to-night . A new suit of clothes , Bertram , devised and executed in less than thirty-six hours ! And a fit , sir ; every item of it ! You 'll be green with envy when you see this coat . I 'm ready for you . Handkerchief —?Shouting .John —! Oh , here it is !Switching off the light in the bedroom and appearing , immaculately dressed , in the doorway .Behold !Closing the door and advancing to BERTRAM .How are you , Bertram ?BERTRAM refuses PHILIP 's hand by putting his own behind his back . PHILIP raises his eyebrows .Oh ?A pause .Anything amiss ?Observing BERTRAM 's heated look .You do n't look well , Filson .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Breathing heavily .No , I 'm not well — I mean t'say , I 'm sick with indignation ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: What about ?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: You 've attempted to play us all a rascally trick , Mackworth ; a low , scurvy , contemptible ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Frowning .A trick ?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: I 've just come from Mr. Dunning — a man I 've thought it my duty to employ in the interests of my family — Sillitoe and Dunning , the private-inquiry people ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Private-inquiry people ?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Dunning rang me up an hour ago , and I went down to him . The discovery was n't clinched till this afternoon ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: The discovery ?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Derisively .Ho ! This precious book of yours — “ The Big Drum ” ! A grand success , Mackworth !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Perplexed .I do n't ——

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: “ The Big Drum ” ! Would n't “ The Big Fraud ” be a more suitable title , I mean t'say ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Fraud ?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Reached its twenty-fifth thousand , and the demand still continues ! You and Mr. what'shYpppHeNhishYpppHeNname — Titterton — ought to be publicly exposed , Mackworth ; and if we were in the least spiteful and vindictive ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Tightening his lips .Are you sober , Filson ?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Now , do n't you be insolent , because it wo n't answer .PHILIP winces , but restrains himself .The question is , what are we to do to-night — for Ottoline 's sake , I mean t'say . We must spare her as much shock and distress as possible . I assume you 've sufficient decency left to agree with me there . My father and mother too — they 're quite ignorant of the steps I 've been taking ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Controlling himself with difficulty .My good fellow , will you condescend to explain ——?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Walking away .Oh , it 's no use , Mackworth — this air of innocence !Puffing himself out and strutting to and fro on the left .It 's simply wasted effort , I mean t'say . In five minutes I can have Dunning here with the whole disreputable story . He 's close by — bottom of Chancery Lane . He 'll be at his office till half-past-eleven ——

lg.stage: Between his teeth — thrusting his hands into his trouser-pockets .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: I tried to get on to my father from Dunning 's — to ask his advice , I mean t'say — but he 'd dressed early and gone to one of his clubs , and they could n't tell me which one .Halting and looking at his watch .My suggestion is that you and I should struggle through this farce of a dinner as best we can — as if nothing had happened . I mean t'say — and that I should reserve the disclosure of your caddish conduct till to-morrow . You assent to that course , Mackworth ?Dabbing his forehead with his handkerchief .Thank heaven , the announcement of the engagement has n't appeared !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: In a calm voice .Bertram —pointing to the chair on the left of the smoking-tableBertie , old man —seating himself easily upon the settee on the rightyou 're your sister 's brother and I 'm not going to lose my temper ——

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Sneeringly .My dear sir ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Leaning back and crossing his legs .One thing I seem to grasp clearly ; and that is that , while I 've been endeavouring to conciliate you , and make a pal of you , you 've been leaguing yourself with a tame detective with the idea of injuring me in some way with Ottoline and your father and mother .Folding his arms .That 's correct , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: With a disdainful shrug .If you think it will benefit you to distort my motives , Mackworth , pray do so .Returning to the middle of the room .What I 've done , I 've done , as I 've already stated , from a sheer sense of duty ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Again pointing to the chair .Please ! You 'll look less formidable , old man ——

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Sitting , haughtily .Knowing what depended on the fate of your book , I felt from the first that you might be unscrupulous enough to induce your publisher to represent it as being a popular success — in order to impose on us , I mean t'say — though actually it was another of your failures to hit the mark ; and when Titterton started blowing the trumpet so loudly , my suspicions increased .PHILIP slowly unfolds his arms .As for desiring to injure you with my family at any price , I scorn the charge . I 've had the delicacy to refrain from even mentioning my suspicions to my father and mother , let alone Ottoline .Putting his necktie straight and smoothing his hair and his slightly crumpled shirt-front .Deeply as I regret your connection with my sister , I should have been only too happy , I mean t'say , if my poor opinion of you had been falsified .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: His hands clenched , but preserving his suavity .Extremely grateful to you , Bertie . I see ! And so , burdened by these suspicions , you carried them to Mr .— Mr. Gunning ?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Dunning . I did n't regard it as a job for a respectable solicitor ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Politely .Did n't you !

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Not that there 's anything against Dunning ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Uncrossing his legs and sitting upright .Well , that brings us to the point , does n't it ?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: The point ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: The precise , and illuminating , details of the fable your friend at the bottom of Chancery Lane is fooling you with .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: In a pitying tone .Oh , my dear Mackworth ! I repeat , it 's no use your adopting this attitude . You do n't realize how completely you 're bowled over , I mean t'say . Dunning 's got incontestable proofs ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Jumping up , unable to repress himself any longer .Damn the impudent scoundrel ——!

div.stage: The bell rings .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Listening .Your bell !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Striding to the left and then to the fireplace .You said he 's still at his office , did n't you ?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Rising .Yes .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Pointing to the telephone , imperatively .Get him here at once .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Rather taken aback .At once ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: I 'll deal with this gentleman promptly .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Icily .Not before Ottoline and my parents , I hope ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Seizing the poker and attacking the fire furiously .Before Ottoline and your parents .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: A most painful scene for them , I mean t'say ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: A painful scene for you and Mr. Dunning .

lg.l: After dinner — when they 've gone — you and I 'll go down to

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Flinging the poker into the grate and facing BERTRAM .Confound you , you do n't suppose I 'm going to act on your suggestion , and grin through a long meal with this between us !Pointing to the telephone again .Ring him up , you treacherous little whelp — quick !Advancing .If you wo n't ——!

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Bristling .Oh , very good !Pausing on his way to the telephone and addressing PHILIP with an evil expression .You were always a bully and a blusterer , Mackworth ; but , take my word for it , if you fancy you can bully Mr. Dunning , and bluster to my family , with any satisfactory results to yourself , you 're vastly mistaken .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Gruffly .I beg your pardon ; sorry I exploded .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Scowling .It 's of no consequence .At the telephone , his ear to the receiver .I am absolutely indifferent to your vulgar abuse , I mean t'say .

div.stage: JOHN announces ROOPE . Note : ROOPE and the rest of the guests divest themselves of their overcoats , wraps , etc ., in the vestibule before entering the room .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Mr. Roope .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Greeting PHILIP as JOHN withdraws .Am I the first ——?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Glancing at BERTRAM .No .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Speaking into the telephone .Holborn , three eight nine eight .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Waving his hand to Bertram .Ah ! How are you , my dear Mr. Filson ?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: To ROOPE , sulkily .How'r you ? Excuse me ——

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: To PHILIP .My dear Phil , these excursions to the east are delightful ; they are positively . The sights fill me with amazement . I ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Cutting him short by leading him to the fireplace .Robbie ——

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Hey ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Grimly , dropping his voice .Are you hungry ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Dear excellent friend , since you put the question so plainly , I do n't mind avowing that I am — devilish hungry . Why ——?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: There may be a slight delay , old chap .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Delay ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Yes , the east has n't exhausted its marvels yet , by a long chalk .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Looking at him curiously .Nothing the matter , Phil ?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Suddenly , into the telephone .That you , Dunning ——?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: To ROOPE .Robbie ——

div.stage: Turning to the fire , PHILIP talks rapidly and energetically to ROOPE in undertones .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Into the telephone .Filson .... Mr. Filson .... I 'm speaking from Gray 's Inn .... Gray 's Inn — Mr. Mackworth 's chambers — 2 , Friars Court .... You 're wanted , Dunning .... Now — immediately .... Yes , jump into a taxicab and come up , will you ?...

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: To PHILIP , aloud , opening his eyes widely .My dear Phil ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: With a big laugh .Ha , ha , ha , ha ——!

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: To PHILIP , angrily .Quiet ! I can n't hear .Into the telephone .I can n't hear ; there 's such a beastly noise going on — what ?... Dash it , you can get something to eat at any time ! I mean to say —!... Eh ?...Irritably .Oh , of course you may have a wash and brush up !... Yes , he is .... You 're coming , then ?... Right ! Goo'bye .

lg.stage: To PHILIP , who has resumed his communication to ROOPE — incredulously .

div.stage: The door-bell rings again .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Ah —!Pausing on his way to the vestibule door — to BERTRAM .Mr. Dunning will favour us with his distinguished company ?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Behind the table on the left , loweringly .In a few minutes . He 's washing .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Washing ? Some of his customers ’ dirty linen ?As he opens the vestibule door , JOHN admits SIR RANDLE FILSON at the outer door .Ah , Sir Randle !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Heartily .Well , Philip , my boy !While JOHN is taking his hat , overcoat , etc .Are my dear wife and daughter here yet ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Not yet .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: I looked in at Brooks 's on my way to you . I had n't been there for months .To JOHN .My muffler in the right-hand pocket . Thank you .Entering and shaking hands with PHILIP .Ha ! They gave me quite a warm welcome . Very gratifying .ROOPE advances .Mr. Roope !Shaking hands with ROOPE as PHILIP shuts the vestibule door .An unexpected pleasure !

lg.l: Er — I am rather an interloper , I 'm afraid , my dear Sir

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Retaining his hand .No .Emphatically .No . This is one of Philip 's many happy inspirations . If my memory is accurate , it was at your charming flat in South Audley Street that he and my darling child —discovering BERTRAM , who is now by the settee on the left .Bertie !Going to him .I have n't seen you all day , Bertie dear .Kissing him on the forehead .Busy , eh ?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Stiffly .Yes , father .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: At the chair on the left of the smoking-table , dryly .Bertram has been telling me how busy he has been , Sir Randle ——

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Not perceiving the general air of restraint .That reminds me —moving , full of importance , to the settee on the right — feeling in his breast-pocketthe announcement of the engagement , Philip —seating himself and producing a pocket-bookLady Filson and I drew it up this morning .Hunting among some letters and papers .I believe it is in the conventional form ; but we so thoroughly sympathize with you and Ottoline in your dislike for anything that savours of pomp and flourish that we hesitate , without your sanction , to —selecting a paper and handing it to PHILIPah !To ROOPE , who has returned to the fireplace — over his shoulder .I am treating you as one of ourselves , Mr. Roope ——

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: In a murmur .Dear excellent friend ——!

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: To PHILIP .We propose to insert it only in the three or four principal journals ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Frowning at the paper .Sir Randle ——

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Blandly .Eh ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Have n't you given me the wrong paper ?

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: With a look of alarm , hurriedly putting on his pince-nez and searching in his pocket-book again .The wrong ——?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: This has “ Universal News Agency ” written in the corner of it .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Holding out his hand for the paper , faintly .Oh ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Ignoring SIR RANDLE 's hand — reading .“ The extraordinary stir , which we venture to prophesy will not soon be eclipsed , made by Mr. Philip Mackworth 's recent novel , ‘ The Big Drum , ’ lends additional interest to the announcement of his forthcoming marriage to the beautiful Madame de Chaumié — ”The bell rings . He listens to it , and then goes on reading .“ — the beautiful Madame de Chaumié , daughter of the widely and deservedly popular — the widely and deservedly popular Sir Randle and Lady Filson —— ”

div.stage: After reading it to the end silently , he restores the paper to SIR RANDLE with a smile and a slight bow .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
