sp.p: Collecting himself .Er — Lady Filson and I thought it might be prudent , Philip , to — er — to give a lead to the inevitable comments of the press .Replacing the paper in his pocket-book .If you object , my dear boy ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: With a motion of the head towards the vestibule door .That must be Lady Filson and Ottoline .

div.stage: He goes to the door and opens it . LADY FILSON and OTTOLINE are in the vestibule and JOHN is taking LADY FILSON 's wrap from her .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Brimming over with good humour .Ah , Philip ! Do n't say we 're late !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Lightly .I wo n't .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Entering and shaking hands with him .Your staircase is so dark , it takes an age to climb it .To ROOPE , who comes forward , shaking hands with him .How nice ! Ottoline told me , coming along , that we were to meet you .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Bending over her hand .Dear lady !

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Coming to SIR RANDLE .There you are , Randle !Nodding to BERTRAM , who is sitting aloof in the chair on the extreme left .Bertie darling !SIR RANDLE rises .Are n't these rooms quaint and cosy , Randle ?

lg.l: If ever I had the misfortune to be left alone in the world ——

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Sitting on the settee on the right .Ho , my dear !

div.stage: PHILIP has joined OTTOLINE in the vestibule . He now follows her into the room , shutting the vestibule door . She is elegantly dressed in white and , though she has recovered her usual stateliness and composure , is a picture of radiant happiness .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Giving her hand to ROOPE , who raises it to his lips — sweetly .I am glad you are home , Robbie , and that you are here to-night .To LADY FILSON and SIR RANDLE .Mother — Dad —espying BERTRAMoh , and there 's Bertram — do n't be scandalized , any of you !To ROOPE , resting her hands on his shoulders .Une fois de plus , mon ami , pour vous témoigner ma gratitude !

div.stage: She kisses him . LADY FILSON laughs indulgently , and SIR RANDLE , wagging his head , moves to the fireplace .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Ha , ha , ha ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Ha , ha , ha !Going to the fireplace .Ah , what a lovely fire !To SIR RANDLE , as ROOPE seats himself in the chair by the smoking-table and prepares to make himself agreeable to LADY FILSON .Share it with me , Dad , and let me warm my toes before dinner . I 'm frozen !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Coming to the middle of the room .My dear Ottoline — Lady Filson — Sir Randle — I fear we shall all have time to warm our toes before dinner .ROOPE , who is about to address a remark to LADY FILSON , puts his hand to his mouth , and SIR RANDLE and LADY FILSON look at PHILIP inquiringly .You must n't blame me wholly for the hitch in my poor entertainment ——

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Amiably .The kitchen ! I guess your difficulties , Philip ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: No , nor my kitchen either ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Turning the chair on the nearer side of the fireplace so that it faces the fire .The cook was n't punctual !Installing herself in the chair .Ah , la , la ! Ces cuisinières causent la moitié des ennuis sur cette terre !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Oh , yes , the cook was punctual .His manner hardening a little .The truth is , we are waiting for a Mr. Dunning .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: From her chair , where she is almost completely hidden from the others — comfortably .Good gracious ! Who 's Mr. Dunning , Philip ?

div.stage: JOHN and the waiter open the big doors . The dining-table , round which the chairs are now arranged , is prettily lighted by shaded candles .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: To JOHN , sharply .John ——

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Yessir ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Tell the cook to keep the dinner back for a little while . Do you hear ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Astonished .Keep dinner back , sir ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Yes . And when Mr. Dunning calls —distinctlyDunning ——

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Yessir .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: I 'll see him . Show him in .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Yessir .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: You may serve dinner as soon as he 's gone . I 'll ring .

div.stage: JOHN and the waiter withdraw into the kitchen , whereupon PHILIP , after watching their departure , deliberately closes the big doors . ROOPE , who has been picking at his nails nervously , rises and steals away to the left , and SIR RANDLE , advancing a step or two , exchanges questioning glances with LADY FILSON .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Laughingly .What a terrible shock ! I was frightened that Philip had sprung a strange guest upon us .As PHILIP is shutting the doors .Vous êtes bien mystérieux , Phil ? Why are we to starve until this Mr. Dunning has come and gone ?

lg.l: Because if I tried to eat without having first disposed of the reptile ,

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Bewildered .Reptile ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Philip !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: At the chair beside the smoking-table — to LADY FILSON .I apologize very humbly for making you and Sir Randle , and dear Ottoline , parties to such unpleasant proceedings , Lady Filson ; but the necessity is forced upon me .Coming forward .Mr. Dunning is one of those crawling creatures who conduct what are known as confidential inquiries . In other words , he 's a private detective — an odd sort of person to present to you !——

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Under her breath .Great heavens !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: And he has lightened your son 's purse , presumably , and crammed his willing ears with some ridiculous , fantastic tale concerning my book — “ The Big Drum . ” Mr. Dunning professes to have discovered that I have conspired with a wicked publisher to deceive you all ; that the book 's another of my miss-hits , and that I 'm a designing rogue and liar .To BERTRAM .Come on , Bertram ; do n't sit there as if you were a stuffed figure ! Speak out , and tell your father and mother what you 've been up to !

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Open-mouthed .Bertie !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Moving towards BERTRAM , mildly .Bertram , my boy ——?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Curling his lip — to PHILIP .Oh , you seem to be getting on exceedingly well without my assistance , Mackworth . I 'm content to hold my tongue till Dunning arrives , I mean t'say .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Approaching LADY FILSON .You see , Lady Filson , Master Bertram is endowed with an exceptionally active brain ; and when I gave those assurances to you and Sir Randle last June , it occurred to him that , in the event of my book failing to attract the market , there was a danger of my palming it off , with the kind aid of my publisher , as the out-and-out triumph I 'd bragged of in advance ; and the loud blasts of Titterton 's trumpet strengthened Master Bertie 's apprehensions .OTTOLINE , unobserved , rises unsteadily and , with her eyes fixed fiercely upon BERTRAM , crosses the room at the back .So what does he do , bless him for his devotion to his belongings ! To safeguard his parents from being jockeyed , and as a brotherly precaution , he enlists the services , on the sly , of the obliging Mr. Dunning . We shall shortly have an opportunity of judging what that individual 's game is .With a shrug .He may have stumbled legitimately into a mare 's nest ; but I doubt it . These ruffians 'll stick at nothing to keep an ingenuous client on the hook —He is interrupted by feeling OTTOLINE 's hand upon his arm . He lays his hand on hers gently .Otto dear ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Clutching him tightly and articulating with an effort .It — it 's infamous — shameful ! My — my brother ! It 's infamous !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Oh , it 'll be all over in ten minutes . And then Bertie and I will shake hands — wo n't we , Bertie ?— and forget the wretched incident ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Confronting BERTRAM , trembling with passion .How dare you ! How dare you meddle with my affairs — mine and Mr. Mackworth 's ! How dare you !

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Straightening himself .Look heah , Ottoline ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Stand up when I speak to you !

div.stage: BERTRAM gets to his feet in a hurry .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Appealingly .Otto ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: To BERTRAM .All your life you 've been paltry , odious , detestable ——

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Look heah ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: But this ! My God ! For you — for any of us — to impugn the honesty of a man whose shadow we 're not fit to walk in ——!

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: To LADY FILSON — pained .Winifred ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: To BERTRAM .You — you — you 're no better than your common , hired spy ——!

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Rising and going to OTTOLINE .My child , remember ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Clenching her hands and hissing her words at BERTRAM .C'est la vérité ! Tu n'es qu'une canaille — une vile canaille ——!

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Control yourself , I beg !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: To LADY FILSON .Leave me alone ——!

div.stage: She passes LADY FILSON and sits on the settee on the right with glittering eyes and heaving bosom . PHILIP has withdrawn to the fireplace and is standing looking into the fire .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: To BERTRAM .Bertie dear , I 'm surprised at you ! To do a thing like this behind our backs !

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: My dear mother , I knew that you and father would n't do it ——

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: I should think not , indeed !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: To BERTRAM .Your mother and I !

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Horrified at the notion .Oh !

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Upon my word , this is rather rough !Walking away .I mean to say ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Turning .We must n't be too hard on poor Bertram , Lady Filson ——

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Pacing the room near the big doors .Poor Bertram ! Ho !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: To PHILIP .I trust we are never unduly hard on our children , my dear Philip ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: To do him justice , he was most anxious to postpone these dreadful revelations till to-morrow ——

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Exactly !Throwing himself into the chair between the big doors and the vestibule door .I predicted a scene ! I predicted a scene !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: To SIR RANDLE and LADY FILSON , penitently .Perhaps it would have been wiser of me — more considerate — to have complied with his wishes . But I was in a fury — naturally ——

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Sitting on the settee on the left .Naturally .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: And excusably . I myself , in similar circumstances ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Rubbing his head .Why the deuce could n't he have kept his twopenny thunderbolt in his pocket for a few hours , instead of launching it to-night and spoiling our sole à la Morny and our ris de veau ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Gradually composing herself and regaining her dignityP-P-Philip ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Coming to the smoking-table .Eh ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Passing her handkerchief over her lips .Need you — need you see this man to-night ? Ca n't you stop him coming — or send him away ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Not see him ——?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Why — why should you stoop to see him at all ? Why should n't the matter be allowed to drop — to drop ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Drop !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: It — it 's too monstrous ; too absurd .To BERTRAM , with a laugh .Ha , ha , ha ! Bertie — Bertie dear ——

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Sullenly .Yes ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Ha , ha ! I almost scared you out of your wits , did n't I ?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: You 've behaved excessively rudely ——

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Bertram — Bertram ——

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: I mean to say , mother ! What becomes of family loyalty ——?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: To BERTRAM , coaxingly .Forgive me , Bertram . I 'm ashamed of my violent outburst . Forgive me ——

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Who has been effacing himself behind the table on the left , appearing at the nearer end of the table .Er — dear excellent friends —SIR RANDLE and LADY FILSON look at ROOPE as if he had fallen from the skies , and BERTRAM stares at him resentfully .dear excellent friends , if I may be permitted to make an observation ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: To ROOPE .Go ahead , old man .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: In my opinion , it would be a thousand pities not to see Mr. Dunning to-night , and have done with him .Cheerfully .The fish is ruined — we must resign ourselves to that ;sitting in the chair on the extreme leftbut the other dishes , if the cook is fairly competent ——

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Advancing .Mr. Roope 's opinion is my opinion also .Ponderously .As to whether Lady Filson and my daughter should withdraw into an adjoining room ——

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: I feel with Philip ; we could n't sit down to dinner with this cloud hanging over us ——

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Sitting in the chair by the smoking-table .Impossible ! I must be frank . Impossible !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Dear Madame de Chaumié will pardon me for differing with her , but you can n't very well ignore even a fellow of this stamp —glancing at BERTRAMespecially , if I understand aright , my excellent friend over there still persists ——

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Morosely .Yes , you do understand aright , Roope . I 've every confidence in Dunning , I mean t'say ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Turning away , angrily .Oh ——!

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Severely .Bertie ——!

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Bertram , my boy ——!

div.stage: The bell rings . There is a short silence , and then BERTRAM rises and pulls down his waistcoat portentously .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Here he is .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: To LADY FILSON , in a low voice .Mother ——?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: To PHILIP .Do you wish us to withdraw , Philip ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Sitting at the writing-table .Not at all , Lady Filson .Switching on the light of the library-lamp , sternly .On the contrary , I should like you both to remain .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: To OTTOLINE .Otto dear ——?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Adjusting a comb in her hair .Oh , certainly , mother , I 'll stay .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Arranging her skirt and settling herself majestically .Of this we may be perfectly sure ; when my son finds that he has been misled , purposely or unintentionally , he will be only too ready — too ready ——

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Leaning back in his chair and closing his eyes .That goes without saying , Winifred . A gentleman — an English gentleman ——

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Who is watching the vestibule door — over his shoulder , snappishly .Oh , of course , father , if it turns out that I 've been sold , I 'll eat humble-pie abjectly .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Shaking a finger at BERTRAM .Ha , ha ! I hope you 've brought a voracious appetite with you , dear excellent friend .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: To ROOPE , exasperated .Look heah , Mr. Roope ——!

div.stage: The vestibule door opens and JOHN announces DUNNING .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Mr. Dunning .

div.stage: DUNNING enters and JOHN retires . MR. ALFRED DUNNING is a spruce , middle-aged , shrewd-faced man with an affable but rather curt manner . He is in his hat and overcoat .

sp.speaker: DUNNING
sp.p: To BERTRAM .Have n't kept you long , have I ? I just had a cup o ’ cocoa —He checks himself on seeing so large an assembly , removes his hat , and includes everybody in a summary bow .Evening .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: To DUNNING .Larger gathering than you expected .Indicating the various personages by a glance .Sir Randle and Lady Filson — my father and mother ——

sp.speaker: DUNNING
sp.p: To SIR RANDLE and LADY FILSON .Evening .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: My sister , Madame de Chaumié ——

sp.speaker: DUNNING
sp.p: To OTTOLINE .Evening .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Mr. Roope — Mr. Mackworth ——

sp.speaker: DUNNING
sp.p: To them .Evening .

div.stage: SIR RANDLE , LADY FILSON , and ROOPE , looking at DUNNING out of the corners of their eyes , acknowledge the introduction by a slight movement . PHILIP nods unpleasantly . OTTOLINE , with a stony countenance , also eyes DUNNING askance , and gives the barest possible inclination of her head on being named .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Bringing forward the chair on which he has been sitting and planting it nearer to SIR RANDLE and LADY FILSON — to DUNNING .I suppose you may ——

sp.speaker: DUNNING
sp.p: Taking off his gloves and overcoat — to PHILIP .D'ye mind if I slip my coat off , Mr. Mackworth ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Growling .No .

sp.speaker: DUNNING
sp.p: Do n't want to get overheated , and catch the flue . I 've got Mrs. D. in bed with a bad cold , as it is .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: To DUNNING .Now then , Mr. Dunning ! I 'll trouble you to give us an account of your operations in this business from the outset ——

sp.speaker: DUNNING
sp.p: Hanging his coat over the back of the chair .Pleasure .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: The business of Mr. Mackworth 's new book , I mean t'say .

sp.speaker: DUNNING
sp.p: Sitting and placing his hat on the floor .Pleasure .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Middle of October , was n't it , when I ——?

sp.speaker: DUNNING
sp.p: Later .Producing a dog'shYpppHeNeared little memorandum-book and turning its leaves with a moistened thumb .Here we are — the twenty-fourth .To everybody , referring to his notes as he proceeds — glibly .Mr. Filson called on me and Mr. Sillitoe , ladies and gentlemen , on the twenty-fourth of last month with reference to a book by Mr. P. Mackworth — “ The Big Drum ” — published September the second , and drew our attention to the advertisements of Mr. Mackworth 's publisher — Mr. Clifford Titterton , of Charles Street , Adelphi — relating to the same . Mr. F. having made us acquainted with the special circumstances of the case , and furnished us with his reasons for doubting Titterton 's flowery statements ,wetting his thumb again and turning to the next leaf of his note-bookon the following day , the twenty-fifth , I purchased a copy of the said book at Messrs. Blake and Hodgson 's in the Strand , Mr. Hodgson himself informing me in the course of conversation that , as far as his firm was concerned , the book was n't doing anything out of the ordinary .Repeating the thumb process .I then proceeded to pump one of the gals — er — to interrogate one of the assistants — at a circulating library Mrs. D. subscribes to , with a similar result .Turning to the next leaf .My next step ——

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: I wonder whether these elaborate preliminaries ——?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Oh , do n't interrupt , father ! I mean to say ——!

sp.speaker: DUNNING
sp.p: Imperturbably .My next step was to place the book in the hands of a lady whose liter'y judgment is a great deal sounder than mine or Mr. Sillitoe 's — I allude to Mrs. D .— and her report was that , though amusing in parts , she did n't see anything in it to set the Thames on fire .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Laughing in spite of himself .Ha , ha , ha !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Ha , ha !To PHILIP , with mock sympathy .Dear excellent friend !

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: To ROOPE .Yes , all right , Mr. Roope ——!

sp.speaker: DUNNING
sp.p: Turning to the next leaf .I and Mr. Sillitoe then had another confab — er — consultation with Mr. Filson , and we pointed out to him that it was up to his father and mother to challenge Titterton 's assertions and invite proof of their accuracy .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Quietly .Obviously !

sp.speaker: DUNNING
sp.p: Mr. F ., however , giving us to understand that he was acting solely on his own , and that he wished the investigation kept from his family , we proposed a different plan ——

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: To which I reluctantly assented .

sp.speaker: DUNNING
sp.p: To get hold of somebody in Titterton 's office — one of his employees , male or female ——

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Shocked .Oh ! Oh , Bertie !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Rising , with a gesture of disgust .Ah ——!

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: To BERTRAM .Really ! Really , Bertram ——!

div.stage: Seeing OTTOLINE rise , PHILIP also rises and comes to her .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: That a son of mine should countenance ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Panting .Oh , but this is — this is outrageous !To SIR RANDLE and LADY FILSON .Dad — mother — why should we degrade ourselves by listening any further ?To PHILIP .Philip ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Patting her shoulder soothingly .Tsch , tsch , tsch ——!

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: To LADY FILSON and SIR RANDLE .My dear mother — my dear father — you 're so impatient !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: To OTTOLINE .Tsch , tsch ! Go back to the fire and toast your toes again .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: I consider I was fully justified , I mean t'say ——

div.stage: Falteringly OTTOLINE returns to the fireplace . She stands there for a few seconds , clutching the mantel-shelf , and then subsides into the chair before the fire . PHILIP advances to the settee on the right .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: To DUNNING .Sorry we have checked your flow of eloquence , Mr. Dunning , even for a moment .Sitting .I would n't miss a syllable of it .Airily .Do , please , continue .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Looking at his watch .My dear Philip ——!

lg.l: Oh , come to the man — what 's his name ,

lg.stage: Turning several pages of his note-book with his wet thumb .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Merrifield .Passing behind DUNNING and half-seating himself on the further end of the table on the left .Skip everything in between ;sarcasticallymy father and mother are dying for their dinner .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Bertram !

sp.speaker: DUNNING
sp.p: Finding the memorandum he is searching for , and quoting from it .Henry Merrifield — entry clerk to Titterton — left Titterton , after a row , on the fifteenth of the present month ——

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: A stroke of luck — Mr. Merrifield — if ever there was one ! I mean t'say ——

sp.speaker: DUNNING
sp.p: To everybody .Having gleaned certain significant facts from the said Henry Merrifield , ladies and gentlemen ,referring to his notesI paid two visits last week to the offices of Messrs. Hopwood & Co ., of 6 , Carmichael Lane , Walbrook , described in fresh paint on their door as Shipping and General Agents ; and the conclusion I arrived at was that Messrs. Hopwood & Co. were a myth and their offices a blind , the latter consisting of a small room on the ground floor , eight foot by twelve , and their staff of the caretakers of the premises — Mr. and Mrs. Sweasy — an old woman and her husband ——

lg.l: If I may venture to interpose again , what on earth have

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Yes , what have Messrs. Hopwood ——?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Over his shoulder .Ho ! What have Messrs. Hopwood ——!

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: To BERTRAM , pointing to DUNNING .I am addressing this gentleman , dear excellent friend ——

sp.speaker: DUNNING
sp.p: To ROOPE .I 'll tell you , sir .Incisively .It 's to the bogus firm of Hopwood & Co. that the bulk of the volumes of Mr. Mackworth 's new book have been consigned .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Getting off the table , eagerly .Dunning has seen them , I mean t'say ——

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: To BERTRAM , startled .Be silent , Bertie !

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: To BERTRAM , holding her breath .Do be quiet !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Blankly .The — the bulk of the volumes ——?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Staring at DUNNING .The — the bulk of the ——?

sp.speaker: DUNNING
sp.p: To SIR RANDLE and ROOPE .Yes , gentlemen , the books are in a mouldy cellar , also rented by Messrs. Hopwood , at 6 , Carmichael Lane . There 's thousands of them there , in cases — some of the cases with shipping marks on them , some marked for inland delivery . I 've inspected them this afternoon — overhauled them . Mr. Sweasy had gone over to the Borough to see his married niece , and I managed to get the right side of Mrs. S .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Softly , looking from one to the other .Curious ! Curious !

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Forcing a smile .How — how strange !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: To LADY FILSON , a little disturbed .Why strange , dear Lady Filson ? Shipping and other marks on the cases ! These people are forwarding agents ——

sp.speaker: DUNNING
sp.p: Showing his teeth .Nobody makes the least effort to despatch the cases , though . That 's singular , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: But ——!

lg.l: My good sir , in the whole of our experience — mine and Mr .
Sillitoe 's — we 've never come across a neater bit of hankey-pankey —
no offence — and if Merrifield had n't smelt a rat ——

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: But — but — but — the cost of it all , my dear Mr. Dunning ! I do n't know much about these things — the expense of manufacturing many thousands of copies of Mr. Mackworth 's new book ——!

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Alertly .Quite so ! Surely , if we were to be deceived , a simpler method could have been found ——?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: With energy .Besides , what has Mr. Titterton to gain by the deception ?

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: True ! True ! What has he to gain ——?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Who is sitting with his hands hanging loosely , utterly bewildered — rousing himself .Good God , yes ! What has Titterton to gain by joining me in a blackguardly scheme to — to — to ——?

sp.speaker: DUNNING
sp.p: To SIR RANDLE and ROOPE .Well , gentlemen , in the first place , it 's plain that Titterton was too fly to risk being easily blown upon ——

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: He was prepared to prove that the books have been manufactured and delivered , I mean t'say ——

sp.speaker: DUNNING
sp.p: And in the second place , on the question of expense , the speculation was a tolerably safe one .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Keenly .Speculation ?

sp.speaker: DUNNING
sp.p: Madarme dee Showmeeay being , according to my instructions —to LADY FILSON , after a glance in OTTOLINE 's directionno offence , ladies —to SIR RANDLE and ROOPEMadarme dee Showmeeay being what is usually termed a catch , Mr. Mackworth would have been in a position , after his marriage , to reimburse Titterton ——

div.stage: PHILIP starts to his feet with a cry of rage .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Oh ——!

lg.stage: Jumping up and hurrying to PHILIP — pacifying him .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Grasping ROOPE 's arm .Robbie ——!

div.stage: SIR RANDLE rises and goes to LADY FILSON . She also rises as he approaches her . They gaze at each other with expressionless faces .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: To PHILIP .Where does Titterton live ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Gordon Square .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Pointing to the telephone .Telephone — have him round ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: He 's not in London .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Not ——?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: He 's gone to the Riviera — left this morning .Crossing to SIR RANDLE and LADY FILSON — appealingly .Lady Filson — Sir Randle — you do n't believe that Titterton and I could be guilty of such an arrant piece of knavery , do you ? Ho , ho , ho ! It 's preposterous .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Constrainedly .Frankly — I must be frank — I hardly know what to believe .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Pursing her mouth .We — we hardly know what to believe .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Leaving them .Ah ——!

lg.stage: Who has dropped into the chair by the smoking-table — to SIR RANDLE .
lg.l: Sir Randle — dear excellent friend — let us meet Mr. Dunning to-morrow at
Messrs. Hopwood 's in Carmichael Lane — we three — you and I and

lg.stage: Pacing up and down between the table on the left and the bookcase .
lg.l: Yes , yes — before I wire to Titterton — or see Curtis , his manager ——

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Over his shoulder , to DUNNING .Hey , Mr. Dunning ?

sp.speaker: DUNNING
sp.p: Pleasure .

div.stage: While this has been going on , DUNNING has put his note-book away and risen , gathering up his hat and overcoat as he does so . BERTRAM is now assisting him into his coat .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Advancing a step or two .At what hour ——?

sp.speaker: DUNNING
sp.p: Briskly .Ten-thirty suit you , gentlemen ? SIR RANDLE , PHILIP , and ROOPE .

div.stage: Together . ] Half-past-ten .

lg.stage: Scribbling with a pocket-pencil on his shirt-cuff .

sp.speaker: DUNNING
sp.p: Pulling down his under-coat .I 'll be there .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Lowering his hands suddenly and leaning back in his chair , as if about to administer a poser .By the way , Mr. Dunning , you tell us you have a strong conviction that Messrs. Hopwood & Co. are a myth , and their offices a sham —causticallymay I ask whether you 've tried to ascertain who is the actual tenant of the room and cellar in Carmichael Lane ?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Sniggering .Why , Titterton , of course . I mean to say ——!

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Waving BERTRAM down .Dear excellent friend ——!

sp.speaker: DUNNING
sp.p: Taking up his hat , which he has laid upon the smoking-table — to ROOPE , with a satisfied air .Mr. Sillitoe 's got that in hand , sir . What I have ascertained is that a young feller strolls in occasionally and smokes a cigarette ——

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: And pokes about in the cellar ——

sp.speaker: DUNNING
sp.p: Calls himself Hopwood . But the name written on the lining of his hat —to BERTRAM , carelesslyoh , I forgot to mention this to you , Mr. Filson .Producing his memorandum-book again .Old mother Sweasy was examining the young man 's outdoor apparel the other day .Turning the pages with his wet thumb .The name on the lining of his hat is —finding the entryis “ Westrip . ” “ Leonard Westrip . ”

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Westrip ?

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Leonard — Westrip ?

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Mr. Westrip !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: To DUNNING , blinking .Mr. Westrip is my secretary .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: To DUNNING , agape .He 's my father 's secretary .

sp.speaker: DUNNING
sp.p: To SIR RANDLE .Your seckert'ry ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Coming to the nearer end of the settee on the left .The — the — the fair boy I 've seen in Ennismore Gardens !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Rising and joining SIR RANDLE and LADY FILSON — expressing his amazement by flourishing his arms .Oh , my dear excellent friends ——!

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: To SIR RANDLE .Randle — what — what next ——!

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Closing his eyes .Astounding ! Astounding !

sp.speaker: DUNNING
sp.p: Looking about him , rather aggressively .Well , I seem to have accidentally dropped a bombshell among you ! Will any lady or gentleman kindly oblige with some particulars ——?To OTTOLINE , who checks him with an imperious gesture — changing his tone .I beg your pardon , madarme ——

div.stage: OTTOLINE has left her chair and come to the writing-table , where , with a drawn face and downcast eyes , she is now standing erect .

lg.stage: To LADY FILSON and SIR RANDLE , in a strained voice .

div.stage: Everybody looks at her , surprised at her manner .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Otto dear ——?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: I — I can n't allow you all to be mystified any longer . I — I can clear this matter up .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: You , my darling ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Steadying herself by resting her finger-tips upon the table .The — the explanation is that Mr. Westrip —with a wan smilepoor boy — he would jump into the sea for me if I bade him — the explanation is that Mr. Westrip has been — helping me ——

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Helping you ——?

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Helping you ——?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Inclining her head .Helping me . He — he ——Raising her eyes defiantly and confronting them all .Écoutez ! Robbie Roope has asked who is the actual tenant of the cellar and room in Carmichael Lane .Breathing deeply .I am .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Advancing a few steps .You are ! N-n-nonsense !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Mr. Westrip took the place for me — my arrangement with Titterton made it necessary ——

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: With Titterton ! Then he — he has ——?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Yes . The thousands of copies — packed in the cases with the lying labels — I have bought them — they 're mine ——

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Y-y-yours !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: I — I was afraid the book had failed — and I went to Titterton — and bargained with him ——

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: So — so everything — everything that your brother and Mr .— Mr. Dunning have surmised ——?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Everything , mother — except that I am the culprit , and Mr. Mackworth is the victim .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Ottoline ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Passing her hand over her brow .It — it 's horrible of me to give Titterton away — but — what can I do ?—She turns her back upon them sharply and , leaning against the table , searches for her handkerchief .Oh ! Need Mr. Dunning stay ——?

div.stage: BERTRAM , aghast , nudges DUNNING and hurries to the vestibule door . DUNNING follows him into the vestibule on tiptoe . Slowly and deliberately PHILIP moves to the middle of the room and stands there with his hands clenched , glaring into space . SIR RANDLE , his jaw falling , sits in the chair on the extreme left .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Touching PHILIP 's arm sympathetically .Oh , Philip ——!

sp.speaker: DUNNING
sp.p: To BERTRAM , in a whisper .Phiou ! Rummy development this , Mr. Filson !

lg.stage: To DUNNING , in the same way .
lg.l: I — I 'll see you in the m-m-morning .

sp.speaker: DUNNING
sp.p: Pleasure .Raising his voice .Evening , ladies and gentlemen .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Again sitting on the settee on the left , also searching for her handkerchief .G-g-good night .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Weakly .Good night .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Who has wandered to the bookcase like a man in a trance .Good night .

div.stage: DUNNING disappears , and BERTRAM closes the outer door and comes back into the room . Shutting the vestibule door , he sinks into the chair lately vacated by DUNNING . There is a silence , broken at length by a low , grating laugh from PHILIP .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Ha , ha , ha , ha ! Ha , ha , ha ——!

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Dolefully .Oh , Ottoline — Ottoline ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Ha , ha , ha ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Creeping to the nearer end of the writing-table .H'ssh ! H'ssh ! Philip — Philip ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Loudly .Ho , ho , ho ——!

lg.stage: Making a movement of entreaty towards him .

div.stage: His laughter ceases abruptly and he looks her full in the face .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: After a moment 's pause , bitingly .Thank you — thank you —turning from her and seating himself in the chair by the smoking-table and resting his chin on his fistthank you .

div.stage: Again there is a pause , and then OTTOLINE draws herself up proudly and moves in a stately fashion towards the vestibule door .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: At BERTRAM 's side .Bertram — my cloak ——

div.stage: BERTRAM rises meekly and fetches her cloak .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: Getting to his feet and approaching PHILIP — mournfully .Your mother 's wrap , also , Bertram .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Rising .Yes , let us all go home .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: To PHILIP , laying a hand on his shoulder .My daughter has brought great humiliation upon us — upon her family , my dear Philip — by this — I must be harsh — by this unladylike transaction ——

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: I have never felt so ashamed in my life !

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: To PHILIP .By-and-by I shall be better able to command language in which to express my profound regret .Offering his hand .For the present — good night , and God bless you !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Shaking SIR RANDLE 's hand mechanically .Good night .

div.stage: As SIR RANDLE turns away , LADY FILSON comes to PHILIP . BERTRAM , having helped OTTOLINE with her cloak , now brings LADY FILSON 's wrap from the vestibule . SIR RANDLE takes it from him , and BERTRAM then returns to the vestibule and puts on his overcoat .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: To PHILIP , who rises .You must have us to dinner another time , Philip . If I eat a crust to-night it will be as much as I shall manage .Speaking lower , with genuine feeling .Oh , my dear boy , do n't be too cast down — over your clever book , I mean !Taking him by the shoulders .It 's a cruel disappointment for you — and you do n't deserve it . May I ——?She pulls him to her and kisses him .Good night .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Gratefully .Good night .

div.stage: LADY FILSON leaves PHILIP and looks about for her wrap . SIR RANDLE puts her into it and then goes into the vestibule and wrestles with his overcoat .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Coming to PHILIP , humbly .M — M — Mackworth — I — I ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Kindly .No , no ; do n't you bother , old man ——

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: I — I could kick myself , Mackworth , I could indeed . I 've been a sneak and a cad , I mean t'say , and — and I 'm properly paid out ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Shaking him gently .Why , what are you remorseful for ? You 've only brought out the truth , Bertie ——

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Yes , but I mean to say ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: And I mean to say that I 'm in your debt for showing me that I 've been a vain , credulous ass . Now be off and get some food .Holding out his hand .Good night .

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Wringing PHILIP 's hand .Good night , Mackworth .Turning from PHILIP and seeing ROOPE , who , anxiously following events , is standing by the chair on the extreme left .Good night , Roope .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: G-g-good night .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: Half in the room and half in the vestibule — to ROOPE , remembering his existence .Oh , good night , Mr. Roope !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Good night , dear Lady Filson .

sp.speaker: SIR RANDLE
sp.p: In the vestibule .Good night , Mr. Roope .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Good night . Good night , dear excellent friends .

sp.speaker: LADY FILSON
sp.p: To OTTOLINE , who is lingering by the big doors .Ottoline ——

div.stage: LADY FILSON and BERTRAM join SIR RANDLE in the vestibule and SIR RANDLE opens the outer door . PHILIP , his hands behind him and his chin on his breast , has walked to the fireplace and is standing there looking fixedly into the fire . OTTOLINE slowly comes forward and fingers the back of the chair by the smoking-table .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Good night , Philip .

div.stage: He turns to her , makes her a stiff , formal bow , and faces the fire again .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Advancing to her — under his breath .Oh ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Giving him her hand .Ah !With a plaintive shrug .Vous voyez ! C'est fini après tout !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: No , no ——!

div.stage: With a queenly air she sweeps into the vestibule and follows SIR RANDLE and LADY FILSON out on to the landing . BERTRAM closes the vestibule door , and immediately afterwards the outer door slams .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: To PHILIP , in an agony .No , no , Phil ! It must n't end like this ! Good lord , man , reflect — consider what you 're chucking away ! You 're mad — absolutely mad !PHILIP calmly presses a bell-push at the side of the fireplace .I 'll go after ‘ em — and talk to her . I 'll talk to her .Running to the vestibule door and opening it .Do n't wait for me .Going into the vestibule and grabbing his hat and overcoat .It 's a tiff — a lovers ’ tiff ! It 's nothing but a lovers ’ tiff !Shutting the vestibule door , piteously .Oh , my dear excellent friend ——!

div.stage: JOHN appears , opening one of the big doors a little way . Again the outer door slams .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: To JOHN , sternly .Dinner .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Looking for the guests — dumbfounderedD-d-dinner , sir ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Serve dinner .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: His eyes bolting .The — the — the ladies and gentlemen have gone , sir !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Yes . I 'm dining alone .JOHN vanishes precipitately ; whereupon PHILIP strides to the big doors , thrusts them wide open with a blow of his fists , and sits at the dining-table .END OF THE THIRD ACT

div.head: THE FOURTH ACT

stage.stage: The scene is the same , the light that of a fine winter morning . The big doors are open , and from the dining-room windows , where the curtains are now drawn back , there is a view of some buildings opposite and , through a space between the buildings , of the tops of the bare trees in Gray 's Inn garden .
Save for a chair with a crumpled napkin upon it which stands at the dining-table before the remains of PHILIP 's breakfast , the disposition of the furniture is as when first shown .
A fire is burning in the nearer room .

[ PHILIP , dressed as at the opening of the preceding act , is seated on the settee on the right , moodily puffing at his pipe . ROOPE faces him , in the chair by the smoking-table , with a mournful air . ROOPE is in his overcoat and is nursing his hat .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: To ROOPE , shortly , as if continuing a conversation .Well ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Well , what happened was this . I ——

div.stage: He breaks off to glance over his shoulder into the further room .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Go on . Nobody 'll hear you . John 's out .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: What happened was this . I overtook ‘ em at the bottom of the stairs , and begged ‘ em to let me go back with them to Ennismore Gardens . Lady Filson and I got into one cab , Sir Randle and Madame de Chaumié into another . Bertram Filson slunk off to his club . At Ennismore Gardens we had the most depressin ’ meal I 've ever sat down to , and then Madame Ottoline proposed that I should smoke a cigarette in her boudoir .Distressed .Oh , my dear Phil ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: W-w-what ——?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: I can n't bear to see a woman in tears ; I can n't , positively .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Between his teeth .Confound you , Robbie , who can ! Do n't brag about it .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: At first she swept up and down the room like an outraged Empress . Her skirts created quite a wind . I wo n't attempt to tell you all the bitter things she said ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Of me ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: And of me , dear excellent friend .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Grimly .For your share in the business .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: With a nod .The fatal luncheon in South Audley Street . However , she soon softened , and came and knelt by the fire . And suddenly — you 've seen a child fall on the pavement and cut its knees , have n't you , Phil ?——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Of course I have .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: That 's how she cried . I was really alarmed .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: The — the end of it being ——?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Dismally .The end of it being that she went off to bed , declaring that she recognizes that the breach between you is beyond healing , and that she 's resolved never to cross your path again if she can avoid it .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Laying his pipe aside .Ha !Scowling at ROOPE .And so this is the result of your self-appointed mission , is it ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Hurt .That 's rather ungrateful , Phil ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Starting up and walking away to the left .P'sha !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: If you 'd heard how I reasoned with her ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Striding up and down .What had I better do ? It 's good of you to be here so early .ROOPE rises .I 'm not ungrateful , Robbie . Advise me .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Stiffly .I assume , from your tone , that what you wish to do is to — er ——?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: To abase myself before her ; to grovel at her feet and crave her pardon for my behaviour of last night . What else should I want to do , in God 's name !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Dryly .I see , you 've slept on it .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Laid awake on it .Fiercely .Do I look as if I 'd slept the sleep of a healthy infant ?

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: I do n't know anything about infants , I am happy to say , healthy or ailing ; but certainly your treatment of Madame de Chaumié was atrocious .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Brutal , savage , inhuman !Halting and extending his arms .And what 's been her fault ? She 's dared to love me eagerly , impetuously , uncontrollably — me , a conceited , egotistical fellow who is no more worth her devotion than the pompous beast who opens her father 's front-door ! And because , out of her love , she commits a heedless , impulsive act which deals a blow at my rotten pride , I slap her face and turn my back upon her , and suffer her to leave my rooms as though she 's a charwoman detected in prigging silver from my cash-box !Clasping his brow and groaning .Oh —!In sudden fury at seeing ROOPE thoughtfully examining his hat .Damn it , Robbie , stop fiddling with your hat or you 'll drive me crazy !

div.stage: He sits on the settee on the left and rests his head on his fists . ROOPE hastily deposits his hat on the smoking-table .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Approaching PHILIP coldly .I was considering , dear excellent friend — but perhaps in your present state of irritability ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Holding out his hand penitently .Shut up !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Presenting PHILIP with two fingers .I was considering — when you almost sprang at my throat — I was considering that it is n't at all unlikely that Madame de Chaumié 's frame of mind is a trifle less inflexible this morning . She has slept — or laid awake — on the events of last night too , recollect .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Raising his head .Having been kicked out of this place a few hours ago , her affection for me revives with the rattle of the milk-cans !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Evasively .At any rate , she must be conscious that you were smarting under provocation . She confessed as much during our talk .Magnanimously .Even I admit you had provocation .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: That never influenced a woman , Robbie . Besides , I 've insulted this one before — grossly insulted her , in the old days in Paris ——

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Ancient history ! My advice is — since you invite it — my advice is that you write her a letter ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: I 've composed half-a-dozen already .Pointing to a waste-paper basket by the writing-table .The pieces are in that basket .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: No , no ; not a highly-wrought performance . Simply a line , asking her to receive you .PHILIP rises listlessly .Send it along by messenger .With growing enthusiasm .Look here ! I 'll take it !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Gloomily , his hand on Roope 's shoulder .Ho , ho ! You — you indefatigable old Cupid !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Looking at his watch .Quarter-past-ten .Excitedly .Phil , I bet you a hundred guineas —correcting himselfer — well — five pounds — I bet you five pounds I 'm with you again , with a favourable reply , before twelve !

lg.l: At the worst , I 've earned a fiver .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: As PHILIP sits at the table and takes a sheet of paper and an envelope from a drawer .May I suggest ——?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Dipping his pen in the ink .Fire away , old chap .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Seeking for inspiration by gazing at the ceiling .H 'm —Dictating .“ Forgive me . I forgive you . When may I come to you ? ”To PHILIP .Not another word .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: As he writes .By George , you 've got the romantic touch , Robbie ! If you 'd been a literary bloke , what sellers you 'd have written !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Behind the smoking-table , smoothing his hair complacently .Funny , your remark . As a matter of fact , I used to dabble a little in pen-and-ink as a young man .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Reading , a tender ring in his voice .“ Forgive me . I forgive you . When may I come to you ? ”Adding his signature .“ Philip . ”

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Admirable !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Folding and enclosing the note — catching some of ROOPE 's hopefulness .In the meantime I 'll array myself in my Sunday-best —moistening the envelopeon the chance ——

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Do ; at once .Putting on his hat .She may summon you by telephone ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Addressing the envelope .She gave me a scarf-pin yesterday — such a beauty .Softly .I 'll wear it .Rising and giving the note to ROOPE .Bless you , old boy !

div.stage: ROOPE pockets the note , grasps PHILIP 's hand hurriedly , and bustles to the vestibule door .

lg.l: My quickest way is the Tube to Bayswater , and then a taxi across the

div.stage: He has entered the vestibule — omitting to close the door in his haste — and has opened the outer door when PHILIP calls to him .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Standing behind the smoking-table — with a change of manner .Robbie ——

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Hey ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Robbie —ROOPE returns to PHILIP reluctantly , leaving the outer door open .Oh , Robbie —gripping ROOPE 's armhow I boasted to you of my triumph — my grand victory ! How I swaggered and bellowed , and crowed over you ——!

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Fidgeting to get away .Yes , but we wo n't discuss that now , Phil ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Detaining him .Wait .Brokenly .Robbie — should Ottoline show any inclination to — to patch matters up , you may tell her — as from me — that I — I 've done with it .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Wonderingly .Done with it ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: My career as a writing-man . It 's finished .Hanging his head .I 'm sorry to break faith with her people ; but she may take me , if she will , on her own terms — a poor devil who has proved a duffer at his job , and who is content henceforth to be nothing but her humble slave and dependant .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Energetically .My dear Phil , for heaven 's sake , do n't entertain such a notion ! Abandon your career just when you 're making a noise in the world ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Throwing up his hands .Noise in the world !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: When you 're getting the finest advertisement an author could possibly desire !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Choking .Advertisement ——!

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: I can sympathize with your feeling mortified at not scoring entirely off your own bat ; but , deuce take it , your book is in its thirteenth edition !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Laughing wildly .Ho , ho , ho !Moving to the fireplace .Ha , ha , ha , ha ——!

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Testily .Oh , I 'm glad I amuse you ——!

lg.stage: Coming to the settee on the right .

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: Again preparing to depart .Indeed ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Ha , ha , ha ——!

div.stage: A moment earlier , SIR TIMOTHY BARRADELL has appeared in the vestibule , trying , in the dim light there , to decipher the name on the outer door . Hearing the sound of voices , he turns and reveals himself .

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Looking into the room and encountering ROOPE .Roope !

sp.speaker: ROOPE
sp.p: As they shake hands — astonished .Dear excellent friend , what a surprise !

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Ah , do n't flatter yourself you 're the only early riser in London !Seeing PHILIP .Mr. Mackworth —advancingI found your door open and I took the liberty ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Meeting him in the middle of the room .Sir Timothy Barradell , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: It is .They shake hands , cordially on SIR TIMOTHY 's part , with more formality on PHILIP 's .It 's an unceremonious hour for a call , but if you 'd spare me five minutes ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Civilly .Pray sit down .Joining ROOPE at the entrance to the vestibule .Robbie has to run away ——

lg.stage: Waving a hand to SIR TIMOTHY .

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Laying his hat upon the settee on the right and taking off his gloves .So long !PHILIP and ROOPE stare at SIR TIMOTHY , whose back is towards them . ROOPE gives PHILIP an inquiring look , which PHILIP answers by a shrug and a shake of the head ; and then PHILIP lets ROOPE out and comes back into the room . SIR TIMOTHY turns to him .I 'm afraid you think I 'm presuming on a very slight acquaintance , Mr. Mackworth ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Shutting the vestibule door .Not in the least .

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Anyhow I 'll not waste more of your valuable time than I can help .PHILIP points to the settee and the two men sit , Sir Timothy on the settee , PHILIP in the chair by the smoking-table . SIR TIMOTHY inspects the toes of his boots .Mr. Mackworth , I — I wo n't beat about the bush — it 's a delicate subject I 'm approaching you on .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Leaning back in his chair .Really ?

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: An extremely delicate subject —raising his eyesMadame de Chaumié .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Madame de Chaumié ?

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: In the first place , I suppose you 're aware that I had the temerity to propose marriage to the lady in the summer of this year ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Yes , I 'm aware of it . Madame de Chaumié informed me of the circumstance .

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Nodding .She would ; she would .Straightening himself .Well , Mr. Mackworth , while I was abroad I heard from various sources that you had become a pretty regular visitor at the house of her parents , and that you and she were to be seen together occasionally in the secluded spots of Kensington Gardens ; and I naturally inferred that it was yourself she 'd had the good taste to single out from among her numerous suitors .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: With a smile .I 'd rather you did n't put it in that way , Sir Timothy ; but I guessed yesterday that the facts of the case had reached you through some channel or other .

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Yesterday ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: When Robbie Roope brought me your kind greetings .

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Ah , that 's nice of you !Constrainedly .That 's — nice of you .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Changing his position and unbending .But tell me ! I do n't know yet what you have to say to me about Madame de Chaumié — but why should you find it embarrassing to speak of her to me ?Gently .We 're men of the world , you and I ; and it is n't the rule of life that the prize always goes to the most deserving .With animation .“ And in the world , as in the school , I 'd say , how fate may change and shift ; The prize be sometimes with the fool , The race not always to the swift . The strong may yield , the good may fall , The great man be a vulgar clown , The knave be lifted over all , The kind cast pitilessly down . ” So sang one of the noblest gentlemen who have ever followed my calling !

div.stage: There is a brief silence , and then SIR TIMOTHY rises abruptly and walks to the fireplace . PHILIP looks after him , perplexed .

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Facing the fire .Mr. Mackworth ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Eh ?

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: I saw Bertram Filson last night — her brother .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Pricking up his ears .You did ? Where ?

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: At the club — the Junior Somerset . He came in late , looking a bit out of gear , and ate a mouthful of dinner and drank a whole bottle of Pommery ; and afterwards he joined me in the smoking-room and — and was exceedingly communicative .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Attentively .Oh ?

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: I did n't encourage him to babble —turning‘ twas he that insisted on confiding to me what had occurred ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Occurred ?

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: That you and Madame de Chaumié had had a serious difference , and that there 's small prospect of its being bridged over .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Glaring .Oh , he confided that to you , did he , Sir Timothy ?

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: He did .

lg.stage: Rising and pacing up and down on the left .
lg.l: Filson mean by gossiping about me at a club — me and my relations with

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Advancing a little .Ah , do n't be angry ! The champagne he 'd drunk had loosened his tongue . And then , I 'm a friend of the family ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Infernal puppy !

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Referring to Filson ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Of course .

sp.speaker: Sir Timothy
sp.p: Mildly .Well , whether young Filson 's a puppy or not , now perhaps you begin to appreciate my motive for intruding on you ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Halting .Hardly .

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: You do n't !Rumpling his hair .I 'll try to make it plainer to you .Behind the smoking-table .Er — will I smoke one of your cigarettes ?——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Frigidly polite .Please .

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Taking a cigarette from the box on the table .Mr. Mackworth , if Filson 's prognostications as to the result of the quarrel between you and his sister are fulfilled , it 's my intention , after a decent interval , to renew my appeal to her to marry me .Striking a match .Is that clear ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Perfectly .Stiffly .But all the same , I 'm still at a loss ——

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Lighting his cigarette .At a loss , are you !Warmly .You 're at a loss to understand that I 'm not the sort of man who 'd steal a march upon another where a woman 's concerned , and take advantage of his misfortunes in a dirty manner !Coming to PHILIP .Mackworth — I 'll drop the Mister , if you 've no objection — Mackworth , I promise you I wo n't move a step till I have your assurance that your split with Madame de Chaumié is a mortal one , and that the coast is open to all comers . That 's my part o ’ the bargain , and I expect you on your side to treat me with equal fairness and frankness .Offering his hand .You will ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: My dear Sir Timothy — my dear Barradell —shaking SIR TIMOTHY 's hand heartily .you 're the most chivalrous fellow I 've ever met !

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Walking away .Ah , go on now !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Following him .I apologize sincerely for being so curt .

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Do n't mention it .

lg.l: It 's true , Ottoline and I have had a bad fall out .

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: I gathered ‘ twas something arising out of a book of yours ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Y-y-yes ; a silly affair in which I was utterly in the wrong . I lost my accursed temper — made a disgraceful exhibition of myself .Touching SIR TIMOTHY 's arm .I will be quite straight with you , Barradell — Robbie Roope has just gone to her with a note from me . I do n't want to pain you ; but Robbie and I hope that , after a night 's rest —The bell rings in the vestibule .Excuse me — my servant is n't in .He goes into the vestibule , leaving the door open . SIR TIMOTHY picks up his hat . On opening the outer door , PHILIP confronts OTTOLINE .Otto ——!

lg.stage: In the doorway , giving him both her hands .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Drawing her into the vestibule , his eyes sparkling .No .With a motion of his head .Sir Timothy Barradell ——

div.stage: OTTOLINE passes PHILIP and enters the room , holding out her hand to SIR TIMOTHY . Her eyes are black-rimmed from sleeplessness ; but whatever asperity she has displayed overnight has disappeared , and she is again full of softness and charm .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Sir Tim !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Shutting the outer door — breathing freely .Kind of Sir Timothy to look me up , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: To SIR TIMOTHY .Vous êtes un vaurien ! When did you return ?

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Who has flung his cigarette into the grate — crestfallen .The day before yesterday .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Then I must n't scold you for not having been to see us yet .Wonderingly .You find time to call on Mr. Mackworth , though !

lg.l: I — I was on my way to my solicitors , who are in
Raymond Buildings , and I remembered that I knew Mackworth years ago ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Loitering near the vestibule door , impatient for SIR TIMOTHY 's departure .When I was a rollicking man-about-town , eh , Barradell !

lg.stage: Retaining OTTOLINE 's hand — to her , earnestly .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Yes ?

lg.l: A little bird brought the news to me shortly after
Mackworth — I congratulate you from the core of my heart .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: In a quiet voice .Thank you , dear Sir Timothy .

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: May you both be as happy as you deserve to be , and even happier !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Laughing .Ha , ha , ha !

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Squeezing her hand .Good-bye for the present .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Smilingly .Good-bye .He passes her and joins PHILIP . Unseen by OTTOLINE — who proceeds to loosen her coat at the settee on the right — PHILIP again gives SIR TIMOTHY a vigorous hand-shake . SIR TIMOTHY responds to it disconsolately , and is following PHILIP into the vestibule when he hears OTTOLINE call to him .Sir Tim !

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Turning .Hallo !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Lightly .Is your car here ?

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Brightening .It is .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: You may give me a lift to Bond Street , if your business with your lawyers wo n't keep you long .

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Emphatically .It will not .Beaming .I told you a lie . I 've no business with my lawyers . I came here expressly to improve my acquaintance with the man who 's to be your husband , and for no other purpose .

div.stage: They all laugh merrily .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Ha , ha , ha !To SIR TIMOTHY .Wait for me in South Square , then . I sha'n ' t be many minutes .

sp.speaker: SIR TIMOTHY
sp.p: Going into the vestibule .Ah , I 'd wait an eternity !

div.stage: PHILIP and SIR TIMOTHY shake hands once more , and then PHILIP lets SIR TIMOTHY out .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: As he shuts the outer door .By George , he 's a splendid chap !He comes back into the room , closes the vestibule door , and advances to OTTOLINE and stands before her humbly .Oh , Ottoline — oh , my dear girl ! Shall I go down on my knees to you ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: In a subdued tone .If you do , I shall have to kneel to you , Phil .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Slowly folding her in his arms .Ah ! Ah ! Ah !In her ear .What a night I 've spent !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Almost inaudibly .And I !

div.stage: He seats her upon the settee on the right and sits beside her , linking his hand in hers .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: How merciful this is of you ! I 've just sent you a letter by Robbie Roope , begging you to see me ; you 've missed him .Smiling .It is n't as eloquent as some I started writing at five o'clock this morning . Would you like to hear it ?She nods . He recites his note tenderly .“ Forgive me . I forgive you . When may I come to you ? ” That 's all .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Is n't that eloquent , Phil ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Smiling again .It 's concise — and as long as you forgive me —eyeing her with a shadow of fearyou 're sure you 've forgiven me ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Sure .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Persistently .Without reserve ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Should I be here —indicating their proximityand here — if I had n't ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Pressing her hand to his lips ardently , and then freeing her shoulders from her coat .Take this off ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Gently resisting .Poor Sir Timothy ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: In high spirits .Oh , a little exercise wo n't do Sir Timothy any harm !Helping her to slip her arms out of her coat .Dash it , you might have let me escort you to Bond Street !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: No , no ; your work ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: His brow clouding .W-w-work ——?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: You must n't lose your morning 's work .

div.stage: There is a short pause , and then he rises and moves a few steps away from her . With an impassive countenance , she fingers the buttons of her gloves .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Stroking the pattern of the carpet with his foot .Otto ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Looking up .Yes , Phil ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: I asked Robbie to tell you , if he had the opportunity , that I 've decided to make my farewell salaam to authorship . I 'm no good at it ; I 'm a frost ; I realize it at last . I 've had my final whack on the jaw ; I 've fought — how many rounds ?— and now I take the count and slink out of the ring , beat .Producing his keys , he goes to the cabinet on the right , unlocks it , and selects from several cardboard portfolios one which he carries to the writing-table . While he is doing this , OTTOLINE — still with an expressionless face — rises and moves to the left , where she stands watching him . He opens the portfolio and , with a pained look , handles the sheets of manuscript in it .Ha ! You and I have often talked over this , have n't we , Otto ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Calmly .Often .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Taking the manuscript from the portfolio — thoughtfully .It was to have been — oh , such an advance on my previous stuff — kindlier , less strenuous , more urbane ! Success — success !— had sweetened the gall in me !Glancing at a partly covered page .Here 's where I broke off yesterday .With a shrug .In every man 's life there 's a chapter uncompleted , in one form or another !Throwing the manuscript into the portfolio .Pst ! Get back to your hole ; I 'll burn you later on .He rejoins her . She half turns from him , averting her head .So end my pitiful strivings and ambitions !Laying his hand on her shoulder .Ah , it 's a miserable match you 're making , Ottoline ! My two-hundred-a-year will rig me out suitably , and provide me with tobacco ; and the dribblets coming to me from my old books — through the honest publishers I deserted for Mr . Titterton !— the dribblets coming from my old books will enable me to present you with a nosegay on the anniversaries of our wedding-day , and — by the time your hair 's white — to refund you the money Titterton 's had from you . And there — with a little fame unjustly won , which , thank God , ‘ ll soon die !— there you have the sum of my possessions !Seizing her arms and twisting her round .Oh , but I 'll be your mate , my dear — your loyal companion and protector — comrade and lover ——!

div.stage: He is about to embrace her again , but she keeps him off by placing her hands against his breast .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Steeling herself .Phil ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Unsuspectingly .Eh ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: I arrived at a decision during the night too , Phil .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Do n't — do n't loathe me .Shaking her head gravely .I am not going to marry you .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Staring at her .You 're not going to — marry me ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: No , Philip .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: After another pause .You — you 're overwrought , Otto ; you 've had no sleep . Neither of us has had any sleep ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Oh , but I 'm quite clearheaded ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Bewildered .Why , just now you said you 'd forgiven me — repeated it ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: I do repeat it . If I 've anything to forgive , I forgive you a thousand times ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: And you allowed me to — to take you in my arms ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: You shall take me in your arms again , Phil , once more , before we part , if you wish to . I 'm not a girl , though you call me one ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Sternly .Look here ! You do n't imagine for an instant that I shall accept this ! You ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Ssh ! Try not to be hasty ; try to be reasonable . Listen to me ——

lg.l: You — you mean me to understand that , in consequence of this wretched
Titterton affair , you 've changed your mind , and intend to chuck me !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Yes , I mean you to understand that .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Turning from her indignantly .Oh ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Sitting in the chair by the smoking-table .Philip — Philip —He hesitates , then seats himself on the settee opposite to her . She speaks with great firmness and deliberation .Philip , while you were lying awake last night , or walking about your room , did n't you — think ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Hotly .Think ——!

lg.l: No , no — soberly , steadily , searchingly . Evidently not , cher ami !
Phil , after what has happened , can n't you see me as

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: As you — are ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: An incurably vulgar woman . An incurably common , vulgar woman . Nobody but a woman whose vulgarity is past praying for could have conceived such a scheme as I planned and carried out with that man Clifford Titterton — nobody . This — how shall I term it ?— this refinement of mine is merely on the surface . We women are like the — what 's the name of the little reptile ?— the chameleon , is n't it ? We catch the colour of our surroundings . But what we were , we continue to be — in the grain . The vulgar-minded Ottoline Filson , who captivated , and disgusted , you in Paris is before you at this moment . The only difference is that then she was a natural person , and now she plays les grands rôles .Sitting upright and pressing her temples .Oh , I have fooled myself as well as you , Phil — deluded myself ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: You 're dog-tired , Otto . Your brain 's in a fever . All you 've done , you 've done from your love for me , my dear — your deep , passionate love ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Wincing .Passionate love — parfaitement !Looking at him .But that feeling 's over , Phil .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Over ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Simply .I shall always love you — always — always ; but my passion exhausted itself last night . For months it has borne me along on a wave . It was that that swept me to the door of Titterton 's office in Charles Street , Adelphi ; it was strong enough to drive me to any length . But last night , in those dreadful small hours , the wave beat itself out , and threw me up on to the rocks , and left me shivering — naked — ashamed —drawing a deep breathah , but in my right senses !

div.stage: She unbuttons her left-hand glove , rolls the hand of the glove over her wrist , and takes her engagement-ring from her finger .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Aghast .Otto ! Otto ! What are you doing ! What are you doing !She lays the ring carefully upon the smoking-table and rises and walks away . He rises with her , following her .To-morrow — when you 've had some sleep — to-morrow ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Never . Do n't deceive yourself , Philip .Going to the fireplace .If anything was needed to strengthen my resolution , the announcement you 've just made would supply it .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: On the left .Announcement ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: With regard to your literary work .Turning to him .Ne voyez-vous pas ! I have begun to degrade you already !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Consciously .Degrade me ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Degrade you . If I had n't come into your life again , you would have accepted your reverse — your failure to gain popularity by your latest book — as you 've accepted similar disappointments — with a shrug and a confident snap of your fingers .Advancing .But I 've humbled you — bruised your spirit — shaken your courage ; and now you express your willingness — you !— to throw your pen aside , and tack yourself to my skirts , and to figure meekly for the rest of your existence as “ Mrs. Mackworth 's husband ” !At the nearer end of the writing-table .Mon Dieu ! This is what I have brought you to !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Biting his lip .You — you would n't have me profit by the advertisement I 've got out of “ The Big Drum , ” Ottoline —ironicallythe finest advertisement I could wish for , according to Robbie ! You would n't have me sink as low as that ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: You can write under an alias — a nom de plume — until you 've won your proper place ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Uneasily .Oh , well — perhaps — by-and-by — when we had settled down , you and I — and things had adjusted themselves ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Yes , when you 'd grown sick and weary of your new environment , and had had time to reflect on the horrid trick I 'd employed to get hold of you , and had learned to despise me for it , you 'd creep back to your desk and make an effort to pick up the broken threads !Coming to the settee on the right .Eh bien ! Do you know what would happen then , Phil ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: W-w-what ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Intensely .I should puff you , under the rose — quietly pull the strings — use all the influence I could rake up ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: No , no ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: I should . It 's in my blood . I could n't resist it . Whether you wrote as Jones , or Smith , or Robinson , you 'd find Jones , Smith , or Robinson artfully puffed and paragraphed and thrust under people 's noses in the papers . I 'm an incurably vulgar woman , I tell you !Snatching at her coat — harshly .Ah , que je me connais ; que je me connais !

div.stage: She fumbles for the arm-holes of her coat . He goes to her quickly and they stand holding the coat between them and looking at each other .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: After a silence .You — you 're determined ?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Determined .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: You — you can n't be !

sp.speaker: Ottoline
sp.p: I am — I swear I am .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: After a further silence .Then it is — as you said last night ——?

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: What did I say last night ? I forget .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: In a husky voice .C'est fini — après tout !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Inclining her head .C'est fini — après tout .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Bitterly .Ho ! Ho , ho , ho !Another pause .So when — when April comes — we — we sha'n ' t ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Lowering her eyes — all gentleness again .We sha'n ' t walk under the trees in the Champs-Elysées , Phil ——

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Nor in the Allée de Longchamp — where we ——

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: No , nor in the Allée de Longchamp .

lg.stage: Releasing her coat and thrusting his hands into his trouser-pockets .
lg.l: Somebody else 'll gulp the milk at the Café d'Armenonville ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: And at the Pré-Catalan ——

lg.l: And there 'll be no one to gaze sentimentally at my old windows in the

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Softly .Quarante-trois bis .Sighing .No one .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: With a hollow laugh .Ha , ha , ha ! C'est fini — après tout !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Firmly .C'est fini — après tout .She holds out her coat to him and he helps her into it . Suddenly , while her back is turned to him , he utters a guttural cry and grips her shoulders savagely . She turns in surprise , her hand to her shoulder .Oh , Phil ——!

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Pointing at her .I see ! I see ! I see the end of it ! You 'll marry Barradell ! You 'll marry the fellow who 's cooling his heels down below in South Square !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Placidly , fastening her coat .I may .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Choking .Oh ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: I may , if I marry at all — and he bothers any more about me .

lg.l: Bacon Barradell ! Bacon Barradell ! The wife of

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: With a sad smile .He has social aims ; a vulgar , pushing woman would be a serviceable partner for Sir Tim .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Oh ! Oh —!Dropping on to the settee on the left and burying his face in his hands .Ho , well , more power to him ! He can sell his bacon ; I — I can n't sell my books !

div.stage: Again there is a silence , and then , putting on her left-hand glove , she goes to PHILIP and stands over him compassionately .

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Mon pauvre Philippe , it 's you , not I , who will take another view of things to-morrow .He makes a gesture of dissent .Ah , come , come , come ! You have never loved me as I have loved you . Unconsciously — without perceiving it — one may be half a poseuse ; but at least I 've been sincere in my love for you , and in hungering to be your wife .Giving him her right hand .You 're the best I 've ever known , dear ; by far the best I 've ever known .He presses her hand to his brow convulsively .But when we had our talk in South Audley Street , how did you serve me ? You insisted on my waiting — waiting ; I who had cherished your image in my mind for years ! You guessed I should n't have patience — you almost prophesied as much ; but still — I was to wait !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Inarticulately .Oh , Otto !

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Withdrawing her hand .What did that show , Phil ? It showed — as your compromise with mother and Dad showed afterwards — that the success of the book you were engaged upon came first with you ; that marrying me was to be only an incident in your career ; that you did n't love me sufficiently to bend your pride or vary your programme a jot .He gets to his feet , startled , dumbfoundered . He attempts to speak , but she checks him .H'sh ! H'sh ! I 'm scolding you ; but , for your sake , I would n't have it otherwise . Now that I 'm sane and cool , I would n't have it otherwise .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Struggling for words — thickly .Ottoline — Ottoline —his voice dying awayI ——!

sp.speaker: OTTOLINE
sp.p: Taking his hands in hers .Good-bye . Do n't come downstairs with me . Let me leave you sitting at your table , at work — at work on that incomplete chapter . We shall tumble up against one another , I dare say , at odd times , but this is the last we shall see of each other dans l'intimité ; and I want to print on my memory the sight of you —pointing to the writing-tablethere — keeping your flag flying .Putting her arms round him — in a whisper .Keep your flag flying , Philip ! Do n't — do n't sulk with your art , and be false to yourself , because a trumpery woman has fretted and disturbed you . Keep your flag flying —kissing himmy — my dear hero !

div.stage: She untwines her arms and steps back . Slowly , with his hands hanging loosely , and his chin upon his breast , PHILIP passes her and goes to the writing-table . There , dully and mechanically , he takes the unfinished page of manuscript from the portfolio , arranges it upon the blotting-pad and , seating himself at the table , picks up his pen . Very softly OTTOLINE opens the vestibule door , gives PHILIP a last look over her shoulder , and enters the vestibule , closing the door behind her . There is a pause , during which PHILIP sits staring at his inkstand , and then the outer door slams . With an exclamation , PHILIP drops his pen , leaps up , and rushes to the vestibule door .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Otto ! Otto !Loudly .Ottoline ——!

div.stage: With his hand on the door-handle , he wavers , his eyes shifting wildly to and from the writing-table . Then , with a mighty effort , he pulls himself together , strides to the smoking-table , and loads and lights his pipe . Puffing at his pipe fiercely , he reseats himself before his manuscript and , grabbing his pen , forces himself to write . He has written a word or two when he falters — stops — and lays his head upon his arm on the table .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: His shoulders heaving .Oh , Otto — Otto ——!
